Bonjour à tous
voici ma Lampe de poche batterie externe qui est le fruit de plusieur années de travail et de recherche de l'idée au produit fini opérationnel.

cette Lampe à 2 fonction principales:

  • en priorité bien sûr l'éclairage qui est effectué grâce à une led de 3W (environ 250lm)
  • elle possède aussi une prise USB qui permt de recharger un smartphone,une enceinte bluetooth,un apareil photo,un casque bluetooth etc...

le tout est alimenté grâce à 2 batteries 18650 en parallèle pour plus de capacité

description.text: this person was the thisiner of walkers house

Since I first heard of the idea, that the female toilet-sign is actually a (Super)man with a cape, I wanted to make my own signs with Superman and Wonder Woman. I designed these pictograms a few years ago as vector graphics but back then I didn't have a 3D printer and forgot the files on my computer...

I printed them on a glass bed and they are so extremely light that they stick to my doors without glue, only by their own adhesion!

The background is only 0.3 mm thick, the blue parts are 0.6 mm and the black parts 0.8 mm. This way it is printable with a single extruder by switching the filament between layers.
Just slice it with 0.1 mm layer hight and insert

G1 X10 Y5 ;move nozzle

M0 ;pause print

after the 3. and the 6. layer.
If you don't have a bowden setup, you may also want to home at least the X-axis with G28 X0 after pausing.

EDIT- Added a lower profile version 2.0 with a little more of a lip to help prevent food from being pushed out of the bowl. The bottom is designed differently also to cut down print time a bit.

Every morning my cats enjoy following me though the house issuing blood thirsty meows all the while.
A clear sign they want food..

Even though I would put food in their bowels, they would inspect the food then continue their business of ordering me about in the cat language.

My first thought was that they didn't like the food, so I tried many types and combinations with the same uninterested results.

I finally asked my vet about their picky appetite.
She said they may be experiencing whisker frustration..
I.E, when they eat, their very sensitive whiskers may be rubbing on the edge of the bowl which over stimulates them to the point of distraction and frustration at the prospect of eating.

After some research on frustration free bowls, I thought I would give one a shot before I bought 2 $20 bowls.

So here it is, a shallow bowl that allows your cat to eat without their whiskers hitting the edges.

So far its working great! Their whiskers don't hit the edge of the bowl anymore.
As soon as I put the food down, the cats jump right on it and finish it in one sitting.

These will hold about 1/4 - 1/2 cup of dry food, I suggest smoothing out the surface to prevent any bacteria from being allowed to form in any voids that my be present from printing.

I wouldn't use this for wet food unless you can get it extremely smooth and wash it very well after each use.

author: JDM755

print_settings.Notes:: Printed in PETG.

description.text:
Remote Light Switch

When I built my dedicated printing room, I failed to notice that the switch for the overhead lights was located at the top of the rear wall. This, of course, is not very convenient.

This design has 4 main parts:

The Switch Plate mechanism
The Corner "Pulley"
The Cable "Pulleys"
The Remote Switch mechanism

The Switch Plate mechanism attaches to the switch using existing mounting holes. I was able to use the existing screws, but you may need slightly longer screws depending on your electrical hardware.

The Corner "Pulley" is used to make a horizontal 90 degree turn for the control cables. Although I call it a pulley, there are no rotating parts. I'm using standard 550 cord, which slides easily across the plastic "sheaves".

The Cable "Pulleys" are used both for cable routing along the wall and to make the vertical 90 degree turn down to the Remote Switch.

The Remote Switch pulls on the cables to operate the actual electrical switch.

ASSEMBLY

Determine the amount of cord/cable you will need to make to entire run. Leave plenty of extra in case it's needed. Find the center of the length of cord and mark it.

Mount the RLS_Mount to the electrical box.
Thread your cord through the RLS_Lever until the middle of the cord is centered on the lever.
Mount the lever to the mount using the RLS_Cap and a screw.
Mount the "Pulleys" as needed to make the run over to the remote switch. Keep the cords running in line with the direction of pull. This will make the whole thing easier to operate and reduce stress on the parts.
When making the cord run down to the remote switch, cross the cables. This will make the remote switch turn the electrical switch ON when moved up, and OFF when moved down.
Mount the RLS_Switch_Base in line with the vertical cables.
Run your cords through the RLS_Switch_Lever holes and mount onto the base.

Adjust your cords so they are tight enough to operate the electrical switch when the lever is operated. I secured the cords using a single knot. Depending on how stretchy your cords are, you may have to remove the lever, tighten the cord, retie the knot and then remount the lever.
Once you have your cords adjusted to your liking, remount the lever to the base and secure it using the RLS_Switch_Cap and a screw.

Don't cut the cords too short until you know everything is working correctly and all of the stretch is gone.

The design isn't perfect, but it works great for me. Now I don't have to walk all the way to the back of a dark room to turn the light on and off.

Anycubic Delta

print_settings.Notes:: Print the thrust duct and rudders with 1 perimeter and low infill - like 15% or so. This keeps them light weight but plenty strong.  They need to be light. I recommend using a brim to keep the thrust duct stuck to the build platform. Tall and thin objects like the legs of the thrust duct tend to have  large thermal stress distributions causing them to warp and pull off the bed. a 5mm brim solved my problems. I also recommend printing in PETG or ABS. PLA will be brittle. ABS may cause problems with warping and printing large pieces without an enclosure. PETG is a good mix of strength and printing ease.

title: Brushless R/C Racing Hovercraft - For 200x200 printer

description.text:
Some playing around on a small frozen pond
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GtGw097Tzy4

Edit Dec 21, 2017: I added a new lift duct design. The normal duct is designed to cancel out the motor torque of a clock wise rotating propeller. You can mirror it in your slicer if you have a counter clockwise propeller rotation direction. Additionally, a safety grate has been added which screws to the top of the duct and protects peoples fingers. A grate for the thrust duct is forthcoming.

This is a remix of the original to hovercraft to fit on a 200 x 200 printer. I added reinforcements at the joints of the upper and lower hulls to make sure the seam was strong. I used Welders contact adhesive available on Amazon. Other adhesives such as Goop or E6000 available at Walmart, Lowes, Home Depot would work too. CA/Superglue will work but it's a brittle glue when cured. You want the adhesive to be somewhat flexible but strong or the joint may fail.

Print the thrust duct and rudders with 1 perimeter and low infill - like 15% or so. They need to be light. I recommend using a brim to keep the thrust duct stuck to the build platform. Tall and thin objects like the legs of the thrust duct tend to have large thermal stress distributions causing them to warp and pull off the bed. a 5mm brim solved my problems. The thrust duct requires the use of supports.

I recommend printing in PETG or ABS. PLA will be brittle. ABS may cause problems with warping and printing large pieces without an enclosure. PETG is a good mix of strength and printing ease.

I printed the skirt ring successfully in one piece on my 200 x 200 Makerfarm I3V 8inch printer.

I used pieces of 1.8mm filament as alignment pins. They also act to strengthen the joint.

I am experimenting with a new thrust duct remix design to decrease weight (lower the CG) while increasing durability.

I would also recommend getting the skirt parameters correct using a trash bag, however, use of nylon ripstop material (parachute fabric) is ideal as it's tough, light weight, abrasion resistant and a much better material than a trash bag.

Further remixed parts are coming as I work on the design iterations.

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Print the thrust duct and rudders with 1 perimeter and low infill - like 15% or so. This keeps them light weight but plenty strong. They need to be light. I recommend using a brim to keep the thrust duct stuck to the build platform. Tall and thin objects like the legs of the thrust duct tend to have large thermal stress distributions causing them to warp and pull off the bed. a 5mm brim solved my problems. I also recommend printing in PETG or ABS. PLA will be brittle. ABS may cause problems with warping and printing large pieces without an enclosure. PETG is a good mix of strength and printing ease.

comments.author: GearheadRed

comments.text:
Its working great so far just using two 4 inch twin blade props. I need to get tri blade props to save on rpm for the lift fan but even with just the twin blade she seems to have plenty of lifting power. The thrust fan does ok even with 4 inch twin blade fan though I am sure the proper 5 inch tri blade will work way better. Im using some 2205 2300kv motors on 20amp esc's and 3s 30c 1300mAh battery. I have separate lift and thrust channels. Lift is counter-clockwise rotation and forward only. Thrust is clockwise rotation and bi-directional so I have some reverse. It works fairly well on a quadcopter flight controller but I almost think it would make more sense to use something like a 3 channel rc car transmitter with a wheel and throttle trigger, the pistol grip style ones if that makes sense?.
Ill get some pics of it soon once I get the wiring a bit more tidied up. I was impatient and had some fun with it in the snow with electronics exposed, naturally I killed my lift motor/ESC. Not to worry though I gutted my quadcopter for parts for this project so I had spare bits to get it up and going again in short order. Also super fun, I pulled the FPV setup from the quad and mounted that at the top of the lift grate facing forward but tilted slightly to parallel the lift grate. Its almost like you are siting in the middle of the machine flying it from a cockpit. So far the only thing funky I noticed was the reinforcements on the upper rear hull piece has a weird scaling on one of the vertical walls. It causes the reinforcements to come out small and misaligned but I just used some extra glue to help keep that side stiff. Now to print another and start marking off the track around the house so the wife and I can race....

description.text: This is a model of the USS Horne (DLG/CG-30). The USS Horne was a Belknap-class destroyer leader/cruiser. Named for Admiral Frederick J. Horne, 1880-1959. She served in the United States Navy for more then 26 years, and, following decommissioning, was sunk as a target in June 29 2008.

remixed_from.author: orion411
remixed_from.title: Mount for 18mm Proximity Sensor using stock hotend CR-10

description.text:
A fischertechnik switch used as Z-Probe for an otherwise stock CR-10.

The actual download contains an adapter that screws on the extruder using the stock screws. It has fischertechnik-compatible grooves that are used to hold a switch that is used as a Z-Probe.

Probing procedure:
Mount probe in low position, G28, G29, M500, remount probe in up position or remove completely, G28. Ready to print.

Attribution: My adapter is based on the holders by SBBS1992 and orion411. The fischertechnik grooves are modeled after the ones thomasdr has in his battery case.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

Material: PLA

I printed my adapter left-side down. This way the grooves lie on their side and don't require any overhangs. My printer handled the resulting horizontal holes for the screws just fine.

If you are worried about the hole position you can make a quick test print by placing adapter horizontal and slightly below the build plate. This works around the cutouts for the metal tabs of the cooling cage. In this configuration you can just print one or two layers and see if the holes fit before printing the actual part. If the holes don't fit you can adjust their position in Fusion360.

After printing the adapter, mount it on your CR-10 using the stock screws.
Then, build the fischertechnik assembly and wire it into your printer. The switch needs to be in series with the stock Z-endstop and it needs to be configured as normally-closed. I just used a long servo wire and a JST-XH socket and plug. I didn't cut any stock CR-10 wires.

The switch needs to be below the hotend. After you are done probing, make sure you remount or remove the probe to get it out of the way. I just remount the fischertechnik one groove higher on the 3d-printed adapter.

Finally, you need to update your firmware. I am using Marlin 1.1.6 with a custom configuration based on the CR-10 example config. You can find my changes in two .diff files. The most important settings are:

#define Z_MIN_PROBE_USES_Z_MIN_ENDSTOP_PIN
#define FIX_MOUNTED_PROBE
#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -48  // X offset: -left  +right  [of the nozzle]
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -25  // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0   // Z offset: -below +above  [the nozzle]
#define Z_CLEARANCE_DEPLOY_PROBE   15 // Z Clearance for Deploy/Stow
#define Z_CLEARANCE_BETWEEN_PROBES 3 // Z Clearance between probe points

#define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_BILINEAR

#if ENABLED(AUTO_BED_LEVELING_LINEAR) || ENABLED(AUTO_BED_LEVELING_BILINEAR)

  #define GRID_MAX_POINTS_X 5
  #define GRID_MAX_POINTS_Y GRID_MAX_POINTS_X

  // Set the boundaries for probing (where the probe can reach).
  #define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20
  #define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION X_MAX_POS-55
  #define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20
  #define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION Y_MAX_POS-35

  #define PROBE_Y_FIRST //i suspect this gets slightly higher precision as it stresses the right non-supported side of the gantry less
#endif

#define Z_SAFE_HOMING

#if ENABLED(Z_SAFE_HOMING)
  #define Z_SAFE_HOMING_X_POINT 50    // X point for Z homing when homing all axis (G28).
  #define Z_SAFE_HOMING_Y_POINT 35    // Y point for Z homing when homing all axis (G28).
#endif

In addition to these settings you need to disable a few features to get enough PROGMEM space. I have disabled EXTENDED_CAPABILITIES_REPORT, SDCARD_SORT_ALPHA, ADVANCED_PAUSE_FEATURE, STATUS_MESSAGE_SCROLLING, SHOW_BOOTSCREEN, SHOW_CUSTOM_BOOTSCREEN, EEPROM_CHITCHAT and SPEAKER.

title: Spoolholder improvment for Prusa i3 MK2 MultiMaterial
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Prevent axle separation from bearings and gain space on your desk.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2 MMU

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I recommend a brim for the SpoolholderUpper.stl and SpoolholderLower.stl

Mounting the stand and back.

The SpoolholderStand and SpoolholderBack parts fit together by friction. I added 2 mm holes so you can secure the connection with tiny screws, if you want. Be careful when you stick together the stand and back parts, because the back part breaks easily.

The reason why I created this

The new MultiMaterial spool holders have a tendency on long prints to loose the axels from the bearings. So I designed the SpoolholderUpper.stl to prevent the separation. Then I realized that I can minimize the space, needed for the 4 spools, so I created the rack. You need 4x SpoolholderStand.stl and 2 x SpoolholderBack.stl and 8x SpoolholderUpper.stl and 8x SpoolholderLower.stl.

I've included the SketchUp file, so you can improve on my design.

Happy printing
Andreas

title: 5UP Pencil Sharpener
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Published in Wired Magazine 17.01 This is a design that I put together for PonokoID http://www.ponoko.com/ponoko-id. I came up with the design based on the requirements for a Wired Magazine article. It's a fun and simple design that can be made with a few odds and ends from the local hardware store. I really want to see someone come up with a 5UP design that looks like 5 health bars out of a computer game. Enjoy. The design is free of charge. You can use it on the proviso that you share a small part of your personal expertise in the education of others. You can do this in any way that you wish and your contribution need only be small. If youâ€™re a busy person then you can always contribute to a charity like The Fred Hollows Foundation http://www.hollows.org. For the Wired Article online, see http://www.wired.com/culture/design/multimedia/2008/12/pl_create Toss Your Most Brilliant Product Ideas Into Ponoko.com's Fishbowl
By Sonia Zjawinski ... "What We Wanted
A pencil holder that doubles as a sharpener. What We Got
Frosted acrylic guides channel the pencils into store-bought sharpeners. A handle provides leverage, and the rear panel can be removed for cleaning out the shavings."
...

I've put all of the objects into the one SVG file, although you may want to cut the body and guides out of different materials, as shown in the photographs. The box base should be cut from 6mm material. The pencil guides can be any thickness. The original SketchUp file that I created is also included. You can modify it and then use my "SketchUp SVG Outline Plugin" http://code.google.com/p/sketchup-svg-outline-plugin/ to create different SVG files. See my Instructables http://www.instructables.com/member/flightsofideas/ for more information. The design fits 10x5mm (0.6x0.4in) single hole sharpeners and 6mm (1/4in) threaded rod. There are holes to allow 2M screws which give it a steampunk-ish look. You will also need a handle (you may need to change the spacing and diameter of the screw holes). A cabinet magnet can also be used to keep the rear panel firmly in place. To assemble, glue the box together with PVA or another clear-drying glue. If using ply for the base, simply drive the screws in by hand. If using something like acrylic you will have to pre-drill and perhaps tap holes into perpendicular edges. Use epoxy to glue the sharpeners in place. You may also want to modify the design to include a channel for shavings if the sharpening blade does not sufficiently clear the 6mm material. You can also attach the cabinet magnet (optional) at this stage to the rear panel. Once dry, use the threaded rod to fasten the guides into place. Use nuts and washers to sandwich the guides and the top panel of the box. Add dome nuts to the tops of the threaded rods. To get the threaded rod to the length that I wanted, I simply used a Dremel to cut a single 2ft piece into 6 segments. Attach a nice handle to the box, add pencils, and start sharpening.

description.text:
Surprised this thing didn't already exist! I had to hastily hack together my own way of embedding a Raspberry PI 2 or 3 in a regular PC tower :)

This borrows some OpenSCAD code from https://github.com/Petraea/PCI-Bracket

You will need four self-tapping 2mm x 6mm screws or similar to fasten the Pi.
I am planning to power my Pi with a Molex 5v to microusb cable, but I suspect any spare USB3 port should provide enough power.

Unfortunately it is a tiny bit wider than a single slot so it might block the card next to it.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I use a 10mm brim combined with the default support generation in slic3r. This print will not work without support since parts of the bracket starts in the air.

Carefully bend the bottom of the bracket outwards a bit, it makes it easier to find the guide slot in the PC case when installing. Make sure to remove all support material from the hole for the ethernet cable, it's a tight fit. Depending on your case, the two upper USB ports will probably be blocked after installing. Also take care not to apply too much force, the plastic bracket is quite flimsy due to only being 1.2mm thick (you can increase the thickness in openscad but any more wouldn't fit my tower)

comments.text: This is brilliant! I wanted to embed a Pi 3 in my case to act as a standalone server to free up the main PC for other tasks, found this right away. Looks like there is room to add a HDMI breakout port below the LAN port, maybe using a panel mount extension cable.

print_settings.Notes:: After printing, you need to run some fine sandpaper or steel wool through the track to make it very smooth - the slighted bump will cause the balls  to hang up.  Keep at it until the balls run the entire length of the track without hesitation.

description.text:
This little marble machine uses 6mm Airsoft BB's for the balls. When they get to the bottom, just tap the little thwacker and send them back over the top to the start. It's actually a little more challenging than it looks! See how many balls you can keep going at the same time.

Plus, it prints in one piece (except for the feet) and with no supports!

Watch it go: https://youtu.be/Q6aKoDP1uTw

Printer:

UDIO

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Print OTTMM.STL plus four of the OTMM_foot.STL. The feet should press into the divots in the bottom of the marble machine, but if they are loose, secure them with a drop of superglue.

After printing, you need to run some fine sandpaper or steel wool through the track to make it very smooth - the slighted bump will cause the balls to hang up. Keep at it until the balls run the entire length of the track without hesitation.

Playing with this is a little trickier than is seems, due to the lively action of the thwacker.

Operating the thwacker takes a little technique. For reasons I don't quite understand, it is much easier to press and release the thwacker with a hard object (like a stick or pen tip) than it is with your finger. I'm using a tongue depressor in the video.

If you thwack the ball too hard, it will ricochet out of the track at the far end. There is a sweet spot in the press and release that you'll have to get a feel for.

Lastly, if more than one ball is stacked up at the bottom, the thwacker will launch the first ball upwards, but also send the other balls behind it flying the other way. So as soon as a ball reaches the bottom, send it on its way. The challenge is to see how many balls you can keep moving at the same time.

comments.author: Divinitous

comments.text: The resistors need any value greater than 50 Ohms. The ratio of the value of the resistor regulates the voltage to the cooler. For example, if the inside circuit of the cooler will be a resistor of 100 Ohms, and 150 outside, the cooler will be served 2/5 of 24 volts, or 9.6 volts. Please note that the resistors can withstand higher power current, since otherwise they will burn.

Printer:

Custom Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.5 mm nozzle, 0.2 mm layer height

Infill:

30%

The Base

Make sure the battery goes in and out easily. You can trim the edges of the battery holder to just have enough hangover for the battery to stay in place. Once the box is glued together, it is difficult to exchange it. Therefore I used a rechargeable battery, hence the loose connector you see inside the box.

The electronics

The electronics PBA comes from a disposable camera. There is great instructable from Junophor that exactly describes how to tweak this: http://www.instructables.com/id/High-voltage-power-supply-for-Nixies-CFL-Neon-Gl/

Paint

Paint it in any color you like. I used acrylic paint, silver and bronze.

Design

See the FreeCAD sources how I changed the designs.

Mind that I scaled this box 140% !!!

title: zAxis for corexy printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I build a core-xy printer based on Scribblej's corexy (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:413394) design. However, I didn't like the way the z axis worked, so I designed my own. Actually, I have nothing agains ScribbleJ's, but I don't have access to a large enough laser cutter to make the bed -- especially since I resized the plans to make a printer with 300mm^3 of build volume.

I am planning to build the heat bed support out of more 2020 extrusion.

This design could be used either for a resin printer as well.

Key features:
-Just 3 parts to print per side, only 2 models.
-The top and bottom pieces are the same - both a NEMA17 motor mount, and a 608 bearing mount for the other end of the rod
-easy to access holes for 2020 extrusion mounting.
-Lots of airspace around the motor, less finishing work to do if your printer isn't too precisely calibrated.
-Makes use of SC8LUU bearing blocks mounted with M4's instead of a press-fit holder for LM8UU/LUU bearings.
-Intended for top mounted motors, but could be used either way
-Built for use with acme rod style lead screws

Vitamins needed per axis
[email protected] 8mm linear guide rod
[email protected] SC8LUU bearing blocks + [email protected] M4x16 ish screws to mount the bearing blocks
-NEMA 17 motor
-Motor standoffs, M3 hardware to mount the motor
[email protected] M2.5 or M3 screws and nuts to clamp 8MM rods
-Lead screw with lead nut and flex coupler to motor shaft
-608 bearing to support lead screw

Printer:

HotstuffXY (Homebrew mashup)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I could probably go with much less infill, but I like it strong.
Assembly - Full Assembly - Motor Mount Detail Assembly - Carriage Detail Assembly - Bearing end detail Assembly - where the 2020 goes
Fusion 360. I selected 150mm gap between the 8mm rods, and started sketching out blocks from there and figured out the bolt patterns, and then removed a fair bit of unnecessary stuff.

Printed in PLA 190/30 on to tape. I used 3 perimeter shells in the hope that the part will last well. I used and small brim in order to improve bed adhesion. I used customised supports in Simplify3D to support the most extreme overhangs.
Remove all supports and install alongside https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2494642 "body" component. You will need 2 x 25mm M3 bolts and 2 x M3 nuts to attach this part to the body part.

I used Netfabb to mesh the two parts together and cut away excess here and there.

Parts used:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2544186 - Fan Fang
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2494642 - 40mm heatsink fan mount

This is designed to be used alongside the "body" from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2494642 in order to mount an e3D V6 hotend to the CR-10/CR-10s while being able to keep the stock cooling fans (40mm hotend fan and 4010 radial part cooling fan)

title: MacPi Pro XL v1.9 (Raspberry Pi 3 Case)

description.text:
(please feel welcome to check out, all of my other designs under my profile :P https://www.thingiverse.com/The_Craft_Dude/designs )

This is a Raspberry Pi case, designed to work with the Raspberry Pi 3, it is designed look like the Trash can Mac Pro.

The intention with this case is being used as a small diy desktop PC/Mac Pro alternative.

please note that this model is designed to fit (2x) 40x40x10mm 5V PC fans (colored red in the pictures)

Both the internal fan mound and Raspberry Pi mount, can be mounted with either screws and nuts, or glue, the same counts for the fans (the screw and nut parts, i do not recommend glueing in the fans.

Since could not find a way to mount the pi, so the usb ports was accessible, so i designed this "case" to have a small opening on the back, at the bottom, so you can wire an extension usb out from the inside of the "case", this was the best way i could think of, since not everyone have the same USB hub, but most USB extension cords are shaped more or les the same, and they are cheap and easy to make, so that was what i decided to be used with this case (see picture no.:3)

The idea with this case was also, that this case was supposed to be used with a wireless keyboard an mouse, for the mac like feeling ;)

if there are any problems, please let me know.

PLEASE NOTE!: SOME OF THE FILES ARE BIG, SO NOT EVERYONE MIGHT BE ABLE TO PRINT THIS, UNLESS YOU SPLIT THE FILES INTO DIFFRENT PARTS.<<

v1.9:

  • redesigned top fan mount.
  • modified raspberry pi mount.
  • modified and fixed frame.
  • fixed shell.
  • special thanks to " Melanie_T " for letting me know about some of the problems, and also check out her made version of this, it looks awesome in black and blue :D

(changes to the design might occur unnoticed in the future)

title: Stromer ST1x bike trailer adapter plate for Weber hitch

description.text:
Stromer E-Bike needs an adapter plate for mounting a trailer hitch near back axle. The optionally buyable original ST1x adapter fits Thule chariot hitch but not Weber hitches. For a Weber-Product hitch a 45 degrees setup is required. I asked Weber for a mount solution on ST1x, they answered that at the time (november 17) there is no way to connect a Weber hitch on Stromer ST1x bike. So I designed my own.

I've made some designs to connect a Weber hitch on Stromer St1x. You can print this parts, BUT DO NOT USE FOR REAL TRAILER ON ST1x!
Printing is just for fitting tests. After that you have to make the parts of 4mm steel plate!
Templates for that are provided.

Make all at your own risk and follow regulations and laws in your country about hitches and trailers on E-bikes!

For diy details see Custom Section beneath!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.6

Infill:

30%
All designed in Tinkercad

How to make steel plate:

Make all at your own risk and follow regulations and laws in your country about hitches and trailers on E-bikes!

1) Print Template: ST1x__template.stl
2) Transfer outline, hole centers and bending axles to a flat steel rod 30mm x 4mm (thickness)
3) Bend ST1x side 90 deg upward (for bending you should heat the steel near bending until it’s red)
4) Bend trailer side 45 deg upwards
5) Drill 5.5mm, 6.5mm and 16.5mm holes
6) Grind the hole part
7) Paint the part with 2-3 layers of anti-rust spray
8) Mount the part with M5 25mm upper screw and M6 20mm lower screw, washers and self locking nuts.

Thule_Croozer_plate.stl is just for illustration purposes and something like the plate provided by stromer.Think may fit for Thule chariot and perhaps some croozer hitches. Not very accurate!
Weber_E_NOT_TESTED.stl is just a study, not tested yet, for people that do not want to bend a 4mm steel rod. Theoretically with this plate you can use the Weber E mounting. Just print an test before making it of steel.

This design fits ST1x model. I think it, will not fit on other Stromer models!

author: Wemnix

title: LulzBot TAZ 6 Modular Print Bed Corner Mounts

description.text:
The standard LulzBot corner mounts are undersized for the supplied 10mm steel spacers. In addition, when adding the "Modular Print Bed", the top of glass is proud of the steel spacer. This causes the Z touch-off washers not to be level to the plane of the bed.

The modified corner mounts improve stability support of the steel spacer/washer and provide the necessary space for the bed/glass to fit flush. NinjaFlex material is ideal due to its compression properties.

The modified Z axis min switch mount allows adjustment to prevent interfering with the edge of the modular print bed. ABS or Polycarbonate is sufficient for this part.

Lulzbot Taz-6 modular print bed
https://www.lulzbot.com/store/parts/lulzbot-taz-modular-print-bed-heater
https://www.lulzbot.com/store/parts/lulzbot-taz-glasspei-print-surface

title: Anet a8 e3dv6 carriage with cover - modular version
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Some time ago I have designed e3dv6 carriage with cover. This one:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2097517
This was a quite successfull project. I have been using it with success for a long time. Many people has it in their printers. Some good remixes have been made too.
So I have redesigned it adding new features and updates :P.
For additional info, configuration files and so on check the classic version.

The cover:

  • totally new design of radiator cooling part. It is modular now, You can replace radiator part if it melt
  • hex screw holes to easier nut fitting
  • two accessory hiles of both sides for easy extensions placing.
  • fan duct holes has duct position locking textures
  • more minor adjustments
  • it is fully compatible with old (classic) backplate, so u do not have to change it.

The backplate:

  • It has no changes at all.

The nozzle radiator module:
This is all new module for e3dv6. It has two parts.

  • better air flow than classical one
  • can be replaced if it melts without printing whole cover
  • it prevents from blowing air to the nozzle (some people complained about this issue)
  • it supports blowing or sucking air though the radiator.
  • it has holes to pass though cables from heater, termistor and so on to hide them inside the cover

The Fan ducts:

  • compatible with old cover. (but not vice versa)
  • now the bottom is flat for easier print and better blowing
  • has better position locking "things"

The accessory rail:
This is to mounting additional modules. Especcialy for bed leveling sensors like bltouch or others.

  • small, light and easy to print
  • many mounting holes for cover different sensors.
  • allows to adjust sensor height over the bed
  • can be used in the future for other purposes.
  • can be mou8nted on left or right side of the cover

The bltouch sensor module:
New module for bltouch sensor.

  • adjustable sensor height over the bed by the screw
  • can be easy replaced in case of broke
    Look at the photos to mount it

Led light module:
New module. It makes printing process easier to observe. It is 12v powered.
You need:
-a printed module,
-3 white leds

  • a 100ohm reistor

How to make it work:

  • look here to look how the led circuit has to be soldered. Other led circuits can be designed there too:
    http://ledcalculator.net/default.aspx?values=12,3.2,25,3,0
  • place all leds in their places
  • solder them together.in series. Add a resistor in series too. Now they can be powered 12v.
  • glue the leds on their places.
  • solder a wires to the series ends

That's all.
If U liked it, donate me a beer.I like beer :P

title: Cr-10 printer tower top for brace kit

description.text: Second part of a two print system for stability on the z axis on the cr-10 printers https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TQmtihXdWuw

comments.text: I have no headroom in my enclosure (like 1/4 inch). If I altered the top bracket to be lower and near flush with the top do you anticipate any issue with the design then?
comments.author: Kushty

comments.text: These were designed not to interfere with the z travel of the printer.  If you lower them you run the risk of hitting the brace with the extruder when you are printing at maximum size.  If you don’t print with the top few inches you can probably just print out the turnbuckles and bolt them on directly to the t slot.  Just remember not to go full height in your prints if you decide to go that way.

description.text:
My present for Christmas that I share online for the first time. It is Rudolf, the Red Nose reindeer - jar, who must guide Santas sleight while distributing gifts (nuts in a chocolate). It is an attempt to do something from the bottom of the heart to my family and friends. I also share this simple and cute design to the Thingiverse community for Christmas. I think you all can improve this design and there is still some time to make these funny reindeers until Chrismas.

I have printed this using multiple ABS filaments. ABS-Red for the nose, M-ABS (transparent) for eyes and painted pupils with black acrylic, ABS-Brown for ears and horns. I printed in 0.2, but I think better quality easily can be achieved in higher resolution. I glued all items to a jar using hot-glue.

I used supports only for horns, but I think it might not be not necessary.

P.S. Love this community, thank you all for designing and sharing all your amazing things. Happy Holidays to all!

I liked alot the TUSH (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2047554) but had the issue that the two holder parts slipped away, when trying to put the spool on top, since I use the filament spools in a big Ikea pastic box.
So I decided to design my own stands, simple and useful as the TUSH itself.

I attached two small anti slip pads per stand part, since using only the stands did not help much about the sliding itself, but now the spool holder stays in place and keeps its distance for my filament spool.

I am using a spool roll with about 63mm width, the inner width of the stand is about 48mm which gives enough space for the sppol to fit. The width of the TUSH is about 14mm in my case, which fits very well in the stand. It sligthly slides, but with the weight of the spool and the help of the stand, the TUSH does not slip away. In any case, it could be possible to put a small piece of double-faced tape between the TUSH with the stand. In my case I do not need to do that for now.

  • 4pcs M5x12 or M5x10 screws, HEX head recommended (DIN7380 or DIN912)

I scanned this beloved and worn teddy bear as a Christmas gift for my girlfriend. Before the original was snuggled into scraps and thread, I wanted to immortalize it so she can have a little mini plastic version that might outlast the real one, or have one after passing the original on to our daughter.

I scanned it via photogrammetry and Autodesk Recap. The scan turned out really good, only needed some cleanup where the feet contacted the table and some exaggerating/sharpening on the folds and creases so they'd pop a bit more when printed.

Even without any personal sentiment attached, I think it's a fun little print. I like prints that feel natural and realistic and don't look stiff and too perfectly polished and digital, something that has a little personality. 3D scanning is great for this. I hope to do much more in the future.

Printed switch panel Installed panels Dash view

Copied existing plug

When installing a new chartplotter/fish-finder, the factory Cruise-assist switch was blocked, plus it was in an awkward place to begin with. The cover for the throttle levers had plugs inserted where trim-tab toggles would go on a conventional boat. I removed the plugs, copied the dimensions and designed replacements with a hole for this toggle switch:
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0756YHWH9/ref=nav_timeline_asin?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1
To install, snap the switch into the replacement panel and snap that into the throttle cover. I wired them in parallel with the existing switch on the dash.

This is a drone I am building and thought there may be a few others who might try this. Although the drone is nearly done, it has not yet flown. The equipment has flown, but not with this body. I started out with the x design, then rebuilt it into a H frame that I didn't like and so I have this current design. I have yet to up load files as this is a work in progress.

UPDATE : 02/05/2017
Switched license from CC NC to public domain ! UPDATE : 31/08/2012
  • Finished basic version of x_carriage
  • Finished basic version of Z axis elements
  • Added updated main .scad file (doboz_v2 0.1.scad)
  • Added pictures and video of Z axis
  • Please see the github repository for more up to date information
    • Descriptions
    This is preliminary work for an h-bot configuration based reprap, with a rather large build volume. The main advantage of this kind of setup is its mechanical simplicity, so with that in mind, I plan to make this very easy to build and hopefully just as easy to calibrate etc. This is of course fully parametric! Dependencies
    -Requires the MCad library Specifications
  • H-bot design
  • Maximum build size (not set in stone): 220350400 mm
    • Media
  • first X/Y movement test of prototype (running Marlin firmware with CoreX/Y support enabled)
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a4HLpNbQznU&feature=g-upl
    • -first Z platform movement test:
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IwWGr_ky8B0 More info
    https://github.com/kaosat-dev/Doboz-2

For now this is still in the very early prototyping phase, so almost nothing is in a 100% usable state, but I hope to have a fully working prototype by September.
Until then, expect the files to change a lot !
(and feedback is always welcome) I will update files here regularly , but you can always find the latest version here https://github.com/kaosat-dev/Doboz-2 Things that are finalized:
  • X ends
  • X carriage
  • Z axis elements
    • Next to be finalized:
    Extruder, hot end holder etc Not done at all:
  • "box" structure angle elements : not
    • Bom:(totally incomplete for now)
  • 8mm smooth rods (4X for X/Y axis, 2x for Z axis)
  • lm8UU linear bearings X10
  • 5mm wood plank (used for build platform)
  • 4mm dia nuts & bolts (12mm long) X6 for x_ends

comments.text: With a large build area (i.e. potentially large/heavy objects being printed) and a canterlevered build platform, do you suffer from Z banding or sticking/jamming on the Z axis?  Is it using a regular threaded rod, or acme style?  I am currently designing an H-bot style printer now and was planning on putting guide rods/linear bearings for the Z axis on the sides at the front and one in the middle or the rear to distribute the load evenly, but my Solidoodle 2 is like yours and only has a single drive with 2 smooth rods at the back (and suffers from banding I believe because of this).  Good luck with getting the kinks worked out, I am still at the very early stages of my build!

title: WW2 German Crosses and Soviet Stars for Testors Decals
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My favorite local hobby shops carried nothing like these at all and hazarding an online purchase for something that might not work for me was not a valid option. Oddly enough, this file is not for laser cutting or for 3D printing, but I thought I'd share it in the name of convenience and cost effectiveness. Other sets likely to follow once I get to finishing those armies.

It's a simple graphic file of WW2 armor insignia (in this case German and Soviet) scaled for my 1:150 scale armor collection. Still probably usefull at slightly higher or lower scales too. Anyone with enough skill and the right apps can scale or modify these accordingly. I have left the default paper size as 8.5 x 11 inches - oriented to portrait. What I've presented actually fits onto the Testor's Decal System using the transparent decal set described at https://www.testors.com/product-catalog/testors-brands/testors/tools/decals/ - These decal sheets are half-letter sized. This material should be easily acquired at your favorite local hobby shop or online. Follow the instructions provided by Testors for using their products. I take no responsibility for your errors. I'd experiment on white paper in draft mode to save on ink and to test your print resolutions and scaling before committing to the final product on the Testor's transparent decal paper.

I have skipped on adding white to the German Crosses since access to an inkjet that spews white is either impossible or very expensive and I don't want to sit there and cut out crosses forever from white decal sheets with scissors or an x-acto knife.

I have provided the PDF and a SVG file that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

And... as usual - If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

description.text:
This is a re-CAD of the MakerBot snowman (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33983). I made two different arm positions, 4 different hats, and a hollow version of the body in case anyone wants to print it out of a semitransparent material and put a light in it. Models for the optional eyes, mouth, and buttons are also included (although the snowman does look better with them). The button model can also be glued on top of the ball cap hat as an accent color or extra feature.

I wanted to post this now, before christmas, but I may be making some additions in the future. One thing I wanted to do, but didn't get to, was to make some accessories for the snowman to hold - funny signs, more christmas themed things, a nerf gun, etc.

I went thru and added fillets to all the edges to make it look a little cleaner and to help with ringing on the corners while printing. Fillets on the bottom of the parts helps with removal from the print bed.

I made this model at a 300% scale from the MakerBot version. The arms, hats, body, nose, and buttons should be backwards compatible as long as you find the right scale factor.

title: Anet A8 manual bed leveling
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
this gcode is used to position the extruder near each corner of the bed and keep it there for a period of time.

i cant say this enough
before you start the print lower the bed, because if your bed is too high this may cause a print head collision in up to 4 and possibly between each spot.

first of all in order to use this you must modify the bed holding plate.
simply drill off the threads and use the wing nuts (or buy or print knurled knobs off here), i have had no issues with the screws being loose and needing to be held down during adjustment after the mod.

in order to publish this i had to provide a file. to i provided a file called text.amf. it is not intended to be printed.
please only use and modify the g-code

Printer:

Anet A8

Resolution:

dosent matter

Infill:

dosent matter

Notes:

this is a gcode for manual bed leveling
it is made for a anet a8 but can easily be adapted to any marlin based firmware and possible some others.

before you start the print lower the bed, because if your bed is too high this may cause a print head collision in up to 4 and possibly between each spot.

it was tested using my anet a8 with official marlin compiled with marlin config https://github.com/akaJes/marlin-config

simply preheat your printer, have your leveling tool ready, and once the printer is fully heated start the code.
this code will not extrude any material or retract. see my what code is used section to see exactly what code i used and what it does.

before you start the print lower the bed, because if your bed is too high this may cause a print head collision in up to 4 and possibly between each spot.

bed leveling: the nemesis of 3d printers.

i personaly dont mind manual bed leveling, but what i hate is how you have to do 3 things with 2 hands (adjust the bed height, hold the bed steady so it dosent shift, and manage to slide a piece of paper around.
how the a8 (and many other printers don't have a manual bed leveling feature that will move the motors for you.

so i made one myself based off my experience with a makerbot replicator 2, and limited by marlins available gcode.

this takes care of one 2 tasks in bed leveling,
a) positioning the bed.
b) stopping the bed from moving then screwing things

how to use this

first start by preheating the print bed and nozzle to your printing temperature. i currently don't have spots for this in the file but it is easy enough to add.

then as it is heating jower the print bed or you may cause a head collision and possible melt your print surface

this will move the motor to each corner then keep it frozen there for a few seconds (between 10 and 20 depending on where you are in the process.

the first step is rough leveling, each corner has 20 seconds allotted then the head will move to the next corner.
during this step the print head will lift before each move

after that is fine leveling where you take your leveling tool (i use a folded piece of paper) and get the proper leveling
the head will lift before each move once again
each corner is again allotted 20 seconds

once all corners are done it will go into a checking sequence
now during checking the head will not lift before each move.
each corner is given 10 seconds,
use your piece of paper to verify the nozzle is correct and make quick adjustments

this will repeat the checking process 20 times so once you are happy cancel the print

what gcode was used in this

the file is almost excessively notated
all quotes are taken from the reprap gcode wiki
http://reprap.org/wiki/G-code

G0

G0 : Rapid linear Move
Parameters
Not all parameters need to be used, but at least one has to be used
Xnnn The position to move to on the X axis
Ynnn The position to move to on the Y axis
Znnn The position to move to on the Z axis
Fnnn The feedrate per minute of the move between the starting point and ending point (if supplied)

G0 will move to the cordinatees specified by Xnnn Ynnn or Znnn at the speed specified Fnnn

G4

G4: Dwell
Pause the machine for a period of time.

Parameters
Snnn Time to wait, in seconds (Only on Repetier, Marlin, Smoothieware, and RepRapFirmware 1.16 and later)
Example
G4 S200

i would have loved to just pause and wait for user interaction (BTW thats code M226 http://reprap.org/wiki/G-code#M226:_Gcode_Initiated_Pause) but sadly this code is not available in marlin...

G28

G28: Move to Origin (Home)
Parameters
This command can be used without any additional parameters.
X Flag to go back to the X axis origin
Y Flag to go back to the Y axis origin
Z Flag to go back to the Z axis origin
Examples

G28 ; Home all axes
G28 X Z ; Home the X and Z axes

G90

G90: Set to Absolute Positioning
All coordinates from now on are absolute relative to the origin of the machine. (This is the RepRap default.)

G91

G91: Set to Relative Positioning
All coordinates from now on are relative to the last position. Note: RepRapFirmware latest revision firmware uses M83 to set the extruder to relative mode: extrusion is NOT set to relative by ReprapFirmware on G91: only X,Y and Z are set to relative. By contrast, Marlin (for example) DOES also set extrusion to relative on a G91 command, as well as setting X, Y and Z.

i primaraly use this when homing axis, just to lift z above the resting position so i dont knock over any print that may be on the bed after which i return to absolute positioning

Changelog

12-17-2017 - 20 seconds is really short (for me) so i added one that has all time doubled (manual_bed_leveling 2x time.gcode)

PRE/POST PRINT

1) Have Autism Safety Alert signs printed (will include link/image soon)
2) Laminate or use packing tape to seal and weatherize the sign
3) Trim the edges of the tape so it overhangs no more than about 2mm on all four sides.
4) Print the two parts. Let them cool on the bed before removing so they don't warp (important for ABS)
5) On the rear part, put Acetone+ABS slurry or Gorilla Super Glue Gel (what I used) around the inner corner.
place the sign into the front frame then press the rear into place. I used some good clamps for about 20mins as the gel cured then wiped on some more over the joints to help grab and seal.

Attach twine or keychain rings to make it a packpack accessory, I.D. necklace, etc.
Whole project took less than an hour including designing.

This Central Pneumatic (Harbor Freight Tools) hotdog-style air compressor is a decent buy for the workbench when its on sale for <$40. The lack of built in storage, and the chunky power cable however make a bit inconvenient to store or move around.

These printable accessories give you 1) a convenient place to wrap and secure the power cord, and 2) a rigid place to store your basic attachments.

The cable wraps/hooks should be printed with 100% infill. Mount these using any two screws on the compressor's housing. See the picture for reference.

The accessory mount gets firmly pushed into the opening on the handle. Some hot-glue may be required as I found the opening to be a little elliptical. The little clip included with this part allows you to secure a generic pressure gauge to a generic tire chuck.

description.text:
This is a complete redesign of an old model for printing in PLA. No rafts or brims to cut/clean after removing from the bed, just make sure to print on a good adhesive surface. I find it prints well on a taped bed with ABS juice.

I exported the STL at a needlessly high resolution, so it should scale up nicely.
I've made no alterations to the actual parts, i simply put together a "combo"-STL of 24 links and the two endstops from RotoScan's cable chain files.

It takes quite a while just to generate code for the printer, and the print itself takes 5 to 16 hours depending on layer thickness. (that includes the default raft my Axon 2 program generates). At 0.25mm layers the software calculates 6 hours, 15 minutes on this one.
Be sure to try RotoScans single parts first, so you know how they print etc..

comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Not too familiar with others (slic3r..etc..), but skeinforge has a "multiply" feature, so you can make multiple copies of something in a grid fashion and only have to actually slice one copy of the object. Makes printing things such as this much less painfull. Might be worth looking into, if you ever have to slice all those pieces again.
comments.author: JerZ

comments.text: Although it won't be as compact as what you have done here, so good job on that.  ;)
comments.author: JerZ

comments.text: hi :-)
comments.author: JerZ

comments.text: The main difference between making copies in the geometry and telling the Skeinforge to multiply is that in the first case Skeinforge slices each copy (because it doesn't know they're copies), which is complex and takes a long time, and if Skeinforge multiplies, it slices the geometry once, then copies the generated printer code multiple times, which is much, much faster. On the flip side, you can more intelligently arrange pieces than Skeinforge can. So if you're printing one batch, it's much faster to have Skeinforge multiply, but if you're printing lots of batches, it might be faster in the long run to arrange them manually and pack more into a plate, and print fewer batches.

Quote from orcusomega's notes:

"Requires a total of 8 M4 nylon locknuts. Remove the stock leveling wheels, and use one of the locknuts to keep the screw in place on the hot bed (being the nut all the way to the top,. making the screw stay in place without the need to hold the top with a screwdriver). Then replace the springs. Insert the remaining M4 locknuts into the wheels and thread them on - wala!"

description.text:
While www.thingiverse.com/thing:63275 posted an excellent solution for working with reels of SMD parts, many of us are just using short tape segments from online vendors. In a strip of 10 or 25 pieces, it is difficult to peel the clear tape and then pick parts from the tape with tweezers, especially if the tape rolls over and spills parts! This tool prints easily on small printers, holds several sizes of carrier tape (6,8,10 & 12 mm), and is sized to support both plastic and paper carrier. A small catch tray is molded into the design, so you can simply insert a strip of tape, peel back the clear tape for 1 to 5 cells, then tap the tape and drop the parts into the catch tray.

This is good for prototype and repair operations. The parts on tape are exposed for picking with a small vacuum chuck, if you have one, or a bamboo splint with just a trace of sticky flux on the sharpened tip. OpenSCAD source code included for customization and changes to meet your preferences.

This is my approach to a manually deployable Z probe for the TEVO Tarantula.

It will allow you to change your build plate without reconfiguring the z-offset every time. The design is far from perfect but an easy print and in my opinion quite helpful.

Beware of the fact that your printer will crash right into the build plate when you forget to deploy the sensor!

The necessary z-offset depends on the exact placement of the mount. In my case it is -12.9mm. To calibrate your printer to this value start with a value closer to zero e.g. -10mm and decrease it step by step.

title: Monoprice Select Mini. X Axis Belt Tensioner Mod.

description.text:
This is a mod to modify the X-axis idler end to allow proper tensioning of the stock belt after removing the silly 'cloths pin style' belt tensioner used by default. Those tensioners cause backlash. This does require the x-axis cover to be drilled out as the tensioner screw has to be external. Really easy to do as you can use the printed part as a guide to drill the hole.

I included the STEP file so you can easily adjust the diameter of the holes for the smooth rods if your printer has more/less tolerance than mine.

EDIT: So I guess that running MPSM w/o an X-axis shroud is normal. So I've added versions that you can use that don't require the shroud to be installed.

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oia6pGW7_e4

--------------- INTRODUCING! ----------------

---------->The ODROID XU4 CARPUTER <----------

Built to use an Odroid Xu4, and Vu7 or Vu7+ Odroid Screen.
Prints on Any 200x200x160+ Prusa or other 3D Printer of the same volume.

(NOTE: this project should NOT be printed in PLA. it WILL warp, bend, and Fail due to the Temps the inside of a Car/Truck can rise to on warmer days. ABS or Other High Temp Plastics like PETG are STRONGLY recommended for this project!)

This is a 7" Touch Screen Android CarPuter with super accurate USB GPS, Bluetooth 4, 3.5MM Audio in/out, Wifi, And even a Magnetically Adjustable (sliding/detachable) Screen!
Sketchup file is included for additional customization and resizing as needed!

As an IT Field service Tech of 28 Years, I built this unit out of necessity to replace the smaller screen of the phone, and provide more utility while on the road. There are Pre-Built units that you can certainly purchase to accomplish the same task. But I already HAD the Odroid XU4 and Vu7 Screen from another project, and opted to re-purpose them in something that would get more utilization.

DISCLAIMER!

Some of the following apps/features are ILLEGAL to use while Driving!
You CANNOT use apps that allow you to TYPE while you operate a motor Vehicle in MOST States. CHECK YOUR LOCAL LAWS and DO NOT violate the LAW in your use or application of this device! I AM NOT responsible for your improper use or application of this device in violation of the law.
Please Note also that this device release is for educational/tinkering ONLY!
Pull Over, STOP Safely, Then Use! I am typically in a parking lot BEFORE or AFTER a service call when using this device. Or I STOP and get safe, then do what I need to do.
(Just be Smart Please, don't get yourself killed over what is essentially a nerd toy with some business applications.)

The Main Functions FOR ME are:
--> GPS - HUGE!

SYGIC, G-MAPS, WAZE, OTHERS (Gmouse USB GPS works with ALL of them!)
The USB GPS Units are WAY more responsive and accurate than the ones in your Phone. This is a huge time saver, as it allows me to better anticipate my turns and avoid waiting at extra lights and making U-turns. It also INSTANTLY locates satellites. No Waiting. Even More Time Saved.

--> RepairShopr Dispatch Portal

I use this Calendar/Portal to see my appointments in real time, and to pull up the customer's address for quick-queue of GPS trips. (Zero Typing, Zero Talking to Google...)
With a Bluetooth RII keyboard, I can also sit and make site notes in the privacy of my truck, while listening to my News or Music.

--> Music Streamer

I use Spotify, Pandora, and a multitude of other Free Music services to provide my truck with sound. These all integrate WELL into the setup and allow for controls from other programs, and from the hard buttons on the Car Stereo Head-Unit.

--> Command Center

Digital Speedometer(GPS), App Wheel, Date, Time, Weather, Audio Controls, and even an audio Visualizer... All possible through Car Launcher Pro (Paid Version, WORTH IT IMO)

--> WAZE

Speed-Trap, Cop, and Accident Finder, Real Time Traffic info, Alternative GPS to Google maps, and much more. Even shows you the posted speed limits to a pretty good degree of accuracy. Always keep an Eye on those signs though. Its not always right. Still a GREAT and EXTREMELY useful App.

--> Torque PRO

Pair it together with an ELM327 or Similar Bluetooth OBD-II Scanner and you end up with Real-Time engine info System. Full Spectrum of Digital Gauges, that are customizable into MANY different configurations. For cars, with / without Turbo there are Boost and Vacuum gauges, acceleration gauges, and it Even Reads Engine Codes for most OBD-II Cars / Trucks.
There are other apps out there as well that do this. But Torque Pro (Paid App) Works perfectly for my needs. Decent development, nice and Stable on the Odroid Xu4 Android Images.

--> WiFi Boundary Testing and Ranging

WiFi Testing a Large Property like an Apartment complex or Hotel for Wireless Coverage can be Tedious if you have to walk it. Wifi Analyzer is a GREAT utility that provides an Audible PING for Wifi Strength, and Allows you to Drive a Property and Map the WiFi Boundaries Quickly onto the Site Plan. Exposing coverage gaps with ease, all form the comfort of your AC... (And this is Great when you are down here in Sunny Florida!)

--> Quick Searches and General Information

This tool allows me to STAY online pretty much 24 hours a day with something a lot more useful than simply a tiny phone screen. . whenever my phone is near, my hotspot connects up and I'm all set.

Additional Possible Uses:
  1. Digital LED Signage, Using Neopixels and a Decent battery Setup to run them.
  2. Custom LED, NEON, and other Lighting Controls. For Effects/show lighting.
  3. Custom Fuel system Interface and No2 Controls.
  4. PI/Detective Vehicle and GPS tracking interface for investigations
  5. Backup Camera / Dash Cam.
  6. Vehicle Deploy-able FPV Drone Base Station for Site/Building Inspections and Security.
  7. Rear Head Rest Movies/Video Gaming system for Entertainment of passengers and children.
  8. EV Charge Reporting and Electric Motor, AC, Regenerative, and other Controls
    And so much more I can't think of!

Parts List:

Odroid XU4 SoC computer with EMMC of 32GB + RTC Battery to keep time!
http://www.hardkernel.com/main/products/prdt_info.php?g_code=G143452239825
http://www.hardkernel.com/main/products/prdt_info.php?g_code=G145628097465
http://www.hardkernel.com/main/products/prdt_info.php?g_code=G137508214939
(Fan Cooled Heatsink STRONGLY Recommended for the XU4 in this setting)

Odroid VU7 or VU7+ 5v TouchScreen
http://www.hardkernel.com/main/products/prdt_info.php?g_code=G144549683088

4-5 Port POWERED USB Hub
(Modified Power in cable to Get its 5v power from DC-DC converter listed below)
https://www.amazon.com/4-port-Ultra-Super-Speed-Transfer/dp/B077Z27J5Y/ref=sr_1_6?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1516476278&sr=1-6&keywords=USB+Hub+Powered

1 to 2 Foot USB Extension Cord (Optional Depending on the Hub)
https://www.amazon.com/Extension-VCZHS-Keyboard-Playstation-Printer/dp/B076Z83QTT/ref=sr_1_1?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1516476480&sr=1-1&keywords=USB+extension+cord+short

12v to 5v Supply to run both the Odroid XU4, and the Powered USB Hub. (8 AMP+)
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00C4QVTNU/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s03?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Plus a single 40mm x 40mm x 10mm 12V DC Fan for Cooling up to 10-12 AMPS!
(Printed Case for the DROK DC-DC part is also supplied here)

Odroid USB Nano WIFI Adapter
http://www.hardkernel.com/main/products/prdt_info.php?g_code=G145431421052

Odroid USB Bluetooth 4 Adapter
http://www.hardkernel.com/main/products/prdt_info.php?g_code=G141656580698

Short HDMI Cable, Thin as possible. (for Screen video)
(Vu7 Included HDMI Cable is FAR too fat/Large to use.)
https://www.amazon.com/Ysimda-Flexible-High-speed-Connecter-Supports/dp/B017E85JRE/ref=sr_1_3?s=aht&ie=UTF8&qid=1516561469&sr=1-3&keywords=HDMI+right+angle&refinements=p_n_feature_keywords_four_browse-bin%3A7623518011

Short USB to USB micro cable, Thin as possible. (for Screen power + touch)
(Vu7 Screen comes with this part)

x2 K and J Magnetics round neodymium Magnets. (to Hold Screen in place)
https://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=R822

x1 Roll of ABS Material. Any Color you like of course.
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01MY9WPLM/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
(Works ok, but you get what you pay for. I'm sure I could have found better)

Decent size twisted Pair wire. Nothing too small. Gonna be moving 5 AMPs+

Odroid USB 5.1 Sound Card with Line in (for mic so you can talk to google...)
http://www.hardkernel.com/main/products/prdt_info.php?g_code=G141629380416

Gmouse USB GPS unit, Compatible with Odroid.
http://www.hardkernel.com/main/products/prdt_info.php?g_code=G142502154078

DC Plug for Odroid Xu4
http://www.hardkernel.com/main/products/prdt_info.php?g_code=G141440511056

PC microphone
https://www.amazon.com/Neewer-3-5mm-Hands-Computer-Microphone/dp/B005DJOIHE/ref=sr_1_9?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1516477780&sr=1-9&keywords=3.5mm+microphone&refinements=p_36%3A1253503011

Back to Black, Insta-Dry nail Polish. To finish the Screen Face. (Glossy)
(At Walgreen's)

x1 On/Off toggle Switch. For powering on and off of course!

Uses a combination of m2 and m3 hardware. I also had a few small coarse thread screws laying around from another project, similar in size to coarse thread m2. But you should be able to see what is needed from the hole sizes.

FEATURES THAT COULD/SHOULD BE ADDED!

  1. Auto On/Off with Vehicle Ignition.
    Unfortunately, I have not had enough time or the desire, to work this circuit out and implement it into the design. Maybe down the road. But anyone who wants to can certainly customize one up and show us how its done!

  2. Hard buttons / Joystick control.
    I was considering using a Thumb Stick with a Push button for Hard controls. But couldn't decide where to place such a thing. So, there is that.

  3. Double Din, Fully independent Version, with built in 4-Channel AMP, Line-in/out, Etc...

  4. Clamping system added, for easier mounting into the DIN pocket.
    (Wedge fit + Screws at the moment, makes taking in and out a PITA...)

  5. Sound Reactive Lighting Controls or HAT.
    This would REALLY set this device off from the other stuff out there. No Off the shelf Android Head unit Can currently do this without additional components. A HAT would allow the Xu4 to be a True Custom Car Command Center!

The Sky is the LIMIT!

Happy Customizing!

-Z-

Printer:

FolgerTech Prusa i3 Aluminum

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

30 - 60 %

Notes:

ABS or PETG for best results.
(Expect Warping, Working at the Extreme Edges of your Print Surface, and Layer Separation issues. Heated Enclosure works well. Use Cardboard, CorkBoard, Tin Foil, and a Heat Lamp or Track Lights... Just watch for heat and DON'T leave unattended! )

(Also: Screen Frame Face was corrected to better block out the silver border of the screen itself. Latest part reflects this change)

Assembly and Setup

After printing the Parts, Install the Emmc into the Odroid and Install your Android OS.
Do a Dry run, without installing the unit into your vehicle and make sure everything is working correctly.
I STRONGLY recommend running the unit for several hours to ensure there are no heat issues with your power supply.

DROK supply for me was best when set to about 5.7v
The Vu7 is known to slightly flicker when the XU4 is working hard due to current drop across the 5v Rail. The Power Hub Tries to Fix this, but you gotta turn up the juice a bit. 5.7 Was my "sweet spot" for the least amount of flickering.

Work the CPUs super HARD! Warm them all the way up and put the XU4 under as much load as possible. Bench-marking programs work good for this. You don't want a fire in your dashboard.

If ANY components feel too hot to hold in your hand, they are running FAR too hot to put into an Enclosed Dashboard. Source others and Add Fans...

Find spots for the USB hub and Power that do not come into contact with a chassis ground, or you could have issues with shorts. Make sure all items are properly enclosed with enough venting to protect the electronics.

The Din body Screws into the Surround, or can be used with threaded set tabs and tightened into place that way.

Line out, to an AUX or other source is still an issue on this project. I am still looking for a CLEAN aux out for the Odroid XU4 while its connected to Automotive 12 Volts.
For the moment the unit ONLY provides clean audio via Bluetooth to your Existing Head Unit in your Vehicle.

Some have suggested to try the Line out 3.5mm jack on the Boombonnet.
http://www.hardkernel.com/main/products/prdt_info.php?g_code=G150067146391
And just leaving the little speakers off of it entirely.

Being I2S, it may not suffer from as much noise. The power supply I use here, injected 50% noise into the audio signal. Making it totally unusable.

Noise and Ground loop filters, cut out bass frequencies and other frequencies, and distort the sound on any system using an Amplifier and Subwoofer. Trust me. I Tried them all. None of them sounded good after being placed inline. The noise WAS gone. But so was 50% of my sound frequencies.

Additional considerations...

WARNING

Make sure to use CARE when using Neodymium magnets in ANY project. They are known for coming together and shattering, causing sharp metal to fly off at high speeds. Possibly blinding the user. BE CAREFUL!

Make sure your Magnets are FACED the correct way BEFORE Gluing them into final position! Or you will be prying them out and likely shattering them in the process.

Every single attempt to print this in PLA ended in failure within a few days. It was being warped in the car because of its being inside the hot Dashboard. PLEASE, don't bother.
It won't work.

Otherwise, Enjoy the build, and the End result!

Thanks for reading!

description.text:
This is a remix of the pen holder for the ANET A8.
I made it so it can replace or be connected to the hot end fan.
This might work on the stock ANET configuration but I made it for the E3D carriage.

Use pen_holder_remiix_offset.stl to align the pen (a sharpie in my case) with the hot end (it is close i will update it with another version). This applies to the e3d carriage, I am unsure how it will align on the stock config of the A8.

Use this to convert SVGs to STL files to print: https://rawgit.com/ryancalme/svg-to-stl/master/SVGtoSTL.html

You can also make a one layer thick stl, turn on zhop when going over empty spaces, and then export the file to print.

title: Printable plain bearing with hollow shaft

description.text:
Sometimes you need to pivot around empty space. I am working on a weaving machine, and this requires several threads to spin around a central core which moves axially. Maybe you need this for something of your own!

This is a "plain" bearing: (somewhat rough) plastic bearing on (somewhat rough) plastic. It won't handle high loads or achieve high precision... But sometimes that's OK.

The whole thing is held together with a printed retaining ring and requires NO VITAMINS.

title: Turnigy Evolution Hanger
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This was made to the dimensions of the Evolution and fits like a glove. The extra protrusion on the bottom gives it extra stability since the arms stick out about 65mm from the wall. Also, the cover for the Evolution doesn't have to be removed to mount it on the wall.

I wasn't worried about detail since this is for utility reasons instead of art, but it works very well and holds securely. If anyone needs it modified, please tell me and I'll do what I can to help.

Shout out to user tweetip for their "Minimalistic 220 Quad Hanger" design, as I used it for inspiration. Simple and effective is always a good thing.

I made the outer shell 1.6mm (4 shells) and the infill around 25% to help reinforce the arms. The hooks on the end are necessary to prevent the Evolution from slipping off.

title: BWR Nuclear Fuel Assembly Short Model, 300mm rods, 7X7 Array with 3X3 Water Channel

description.text:
"Build-A-Bundle" Nuclear Fuel Assembly Activity for outreach projects with high-school (STEM) students.
Students press their own pellets and fill one rod. The rest of the bundle is printed and pre-assembled ahead of the lesson.
Accommodations are made for an optional electrical system to light the water channel when the rods are placed in their correct positions. This is the part that is a work in progress.

Update 1-10-2018, added decimated versions of lower tie plate and water channel to lower triangle count and file size. Added an array of 169 pellets for easier print bed layout.
Update 1-12-2018, added solid pellet and solid pellet array. (Pellets with no inner hole. Same outer dimensions).
*Update 3-6-2018, replaced Spacer.stl with version that has holes for active flow, like the LTP and UTP.

3D Printed Parts with eSUN PLA Pro (https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01EKEMB7Q)

  • Lower_Tie_Plate.stl - Qty: 1, Supports: Touching Buildplate, Layers: 0.1mm, Infill: 50%, Wall Thickness: 1.2mm
  • Upper_Tie_Plate.stl - Qty: 1, Supports: Everywhere, Layers: 0.1mm, Infill 50%, Wall Thickness: 1.2mm
  • Spacer.stl - Qty: 1, Supports: No, Layers: 0.1mm, Infill: 30%, Wall Thickness 1.2mm
  • Nut.stl - Optional (instead of Short_Nut when using Upper_Cover) Qty: 1, Supports: No, Layers: 0.1mm, Infill 100%
  • Short_Nut.stl - Optional (instead of Nut when not using Upper_Cover) Qty: 1, Supports: No, Layers: 0.1mm, Infill 100%
  • Pellet.stl - Qty: 1440, Supports: No, Layers: 0.1mm, Infill 100%
  • Cap_Lower.stl: Qty: 40, Supports: No, Layers: 0.1mm, Infill 100%
  • Cap_Upper.stl: Qty: 36, Supports: No, Layers: 0.1mm, Infill 100%
  • Cap_Upper_PLR.stl: Updated 12-26-2017, Qty: 4, Supports: No, Layers: 0.1mm, Infill 100% (PLR= part length rods, for the corner positions)
  • Upper_Cover.stl: Optional if needed to cover electrical components, Qty 2: Supports: No, Layers 0.1mm, Infill 100%

3D Printed Parts with 3D Solutech PETG (https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00VKSVMOY)

  • Water_Channel.stl - Qty: 1, Supports: Touching Buildplate, Layers: 0.2mm: Infill: 100%
  • Teaspoon.stl - Qty: 1, Supports: No, Layers: 0.2mm: Infill: 100% (Approximate volume of one pellet when using coffee cream powder and press)

Non 3D Parts

  • Qty: 40 Polycarbonate Tubes, 3/8"OD X 1/4" ID, cut 36 to 300mm and 4 to 150mm

(https://www.mscdirect.com/product/details/63405914)

  • Qty: 40, Springs for rod upper plenums, 0.24"OD X 0.02" Wire X 2" Free Length

(https://www.mscdirect.com/product/details/03307923

  • Qty: 1, Pellet Press (Note: Punch and die set needs to make 6mm diameter pellets)

(https://www.banggood.com/Pill-Tablet-Press-Machine-Manual-Steel-Pill-Tablet-Maker-p-1182212.html)

  • Coffee creamer for making your own pellets with the press
  • Powdered food coloring to mix with creamer
  • Qty: 1, Pelican Storage/Transport Case

(https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00CVTLIOK)

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Notes:

Using a PEI sheet, sanded with 600 grit sandpaper
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B074XLD5QH

This almost 100% 3D printed dolly slider is thought to be built using 16mm diameter rods salvaged from an old roller switcase.

The model performs quite well dragging about 3 kg of weigth around. This structure is meant to be the hardware part for an extensive arduino based controller featuring multiple options, like speed selesction, duration, endstops, etc

author: rhd555

description.text:
Please enjoy this Sojourner Rover model. I use this model as my first player marker when playing Terraforming Mars. It is designed to give the likeness of the real rover, but with robustness in mind. That is, this model has to be put into a box with many other heavy parts, so it is designed to not easily break.

The model is fairly easy to assemble. You will need to print:

  • 4 of wheel-front-back.stl
  • 2 of middle-wheel.stl
  • 6 of wheel axel-2.stl
  • 2 of combined wheel arm.stl (make sure to mirror one of them).
  • 2 of sensor eye.stl
  • 2 of face bracket.stl
  • 1 of sensor-bar-front.stl
  • 1 of body.stl
  • 1 of battery.stl
  • 1 of solar array.stl

(This is not as large of a print as it seems, the assembled model weighs 39.5g).

The face brackets connect to the sensor-bar-front and then attach to the body. You place the sensor eyes onto body where the sensor bar allows space.

Attach the sensor, battery, and the solar array to the body as well.

Attach the wheels to the combined wheel arms, then attach the wheel axels.

Finally, attach the combined wheel arms to the body.

You will need flush cutters and/or an exacto knife to clean up some edges, but if you have an accurate printer, you will not need to do much. Places that tend to need some work:

  1. the sensor hole on the body may need trimming
  2. the holes to attach the wheels to the wheel arm may need trimming (I print with supports but they still sag a bit)
  3. the axles on front and back may not fit all the way, trim 1mm off the small end (the hole in the wheel arm ends up drooping)
  4. Print the wheel arm with supports as well
  5. Print at a larger scale if you have trouble printing the small parts
  6. Have fun mixing and matching colors!

This little box will hold one Omron ice cube relay, and leaves a little room for wiring. I don't think there is enough room to use wire terminals, but if you solder the wires to the relay there is plenty of room.

I printed this in PLA, .2 layer, 50% infill
