author: TueftelTyp

description.text: Yup

[UPDATE - 4th Feb 2013]
Now with two-alternative support sides - one with a ladder, and one with only the legs and a triangle piece to be glued on. A 3 sided (triangular) wargaming watch-tower model for your savage races. Rat-men, orcs, goblins, beastmen, kobolds, and more will feel right at home atop this vantage point, ready to spot for their allies or rain down bestial death! Seemingly put together with scavenged planks, this rickety construction won't win any architectural prizes, but you can print a lot of them and have your own perimeter line of towers ready to use in under a day. Fast, cheap and just good enough for the job - exactly the savage race way! Height fully assembled = 4" (10cm)
Height to standing surface = 3.5" (9cm)
Widest point = 3.25" (8.25cm) Ideally, I will be adding variation pieces to this Thing - including a support element that includes a ladder, a second-story platform that can be stacked with extra supports, etc. SketchUp file included for those who want to modify it and create your own version!

I recommend 100% fill, 2 shells. Print:
1x Platform
3x Support (of any combination of - Support, LadderSide and TriSide) Trim model for any stray filament.
Recover small triangular prism pieces and keep.
Insert the tabs at the top of the support pieces into the holes in the underside of the platform - one tab per support, three holes in the base. This will be a snug fit.
Using a prism piece as the joint, glue two neighboring support pieces to each other.
Repeat for the other two connection points between the supports.
Finally, glue the support structure to the support platform. It is now ready for priming, painting and decorating.

description.text:
A k-cup holder perfect for storing your French roast!

I made a k-cup holder that uses the tower posted by LeFabShop as a frame for 2 holders that are glued in place. I simply scaled the tower up 4.5X to 202.5mm tall. I created some supports for the arches since I was concerned that could be a bit messy without. With my supports it printed pretty nice.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

I suggest .15 to .2 mm layers and 3 to 4 perimeters if you are using a .4mm nozzle. 15% infill is enough for the tower. I printed the holders with a higher infill- I think it was about 30%.

I have provided two options for the tower. One without supports that you can add your own supports to as you like and one with my support structure.

Remove supports from the tower (if you used my supports). I worked an exacto knife between the supports and arches and carefully cut & worked them free.

Glue the holders in place. The top holder was a good snug fit for me, but could be a bit tight depending on your printer.

title: Emergency Stop switch mount for AM8

description.text:
This is a simple housing for an emergency stop button/power switch for the AM8. Mounts directly to the extrusion wherever you want it using two extra t-nuts and M5 bolts left over from the build. It has a relief in the back for the wires to route under the frame while still sitting flush with the table. I used slightly shorter square rubber feet on my build so my printer may sit a mm or two lower than it would if you used the feet from the AM8 BOM. Measure before printing and since it prints upside down you can slice it to stop printing the model at whatever height is appropriate for your printer.

For the switch I used a cheap uxcell red mushroom emergency stop switch $5.36 on Amazon(https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0094GM004/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1) But any 22mm stop switch should work. I left a decent amount of extra room for wiring and switches of different dimensions.

Printer:

Anet AM8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1-0.2 (Doesn't really matter)

Infill:

Doesn't matter just so its strong enough to hit and not break.

Notes:

If you are printing on glass (or pei film covered glass if you want awesome prints with zero prep) if you set your 1st layer height to squish the first layer a little you will get a nice glassy smooth surface.

title: Skyrim Dragon Skull with Custom Eyes

description.text:
Remix of: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2543584

I love the idea of using marbles or ball bearings for the eyes of creatures so I added eye sockets and rotated and cut the model in half for quickier printing with less support material required. If properly printed, the "eyes" should just snap in. The right side slightly snaps in better than the left, obviously I did something different per side, but not sure what happened. You can test different size eyes by just printing an eye socket and scaling the model if needed. Previous test attempts show that scaling it 164% for 0.625" dia marbles work well - but I have not tried it with this file. Always measure the marbles prior to printing as they have huge variances, hence why I like using Ball Bearings.

Yes, you will have to glue the model together, but zip ties work great for holding the model together while glueing.

Skyrim_375_eyes.stl is for 3/8" (0.375) diameter eyes.

Printer: XYZ Da Vinci Mini
3D Modeler: AutoDesk Inventor with MeshEnabler, AutoDesk Meshmixer
3D Slicer: XYZware

Settings:
No Rafts
YES Supports (scars from supports will be on inside which is nice)
10% Infill
Normal Shell
0.20mm Layer
Medium Speed

Skyrim_375_eyes.stl
Filament: 12.5meters of 1.75mm PLA
Run Time: ~5.5 Hours

author: RickB

description.text:
Space elves for your favorite spaceship battle game.

I haven't tried printing these yet, so there may be updates on the way if I encounter any challenges over the next couple of weeks.

12/20/2017 updated many of the files as the dorsal fins were too thin to properly slice in Cura.

12/20/2017 Another round of updates. I've been printing like a madman and found a few issues. I've thickening up main wings, separating the wings from the escorts (too easy to break while removing the supports). Also Added a grand cruiser suitable for BFGXR.

12/27/2017 Hopefully the final set of updates. After printing myself a small fleet, I've slightly scaled down the size on the cruisers and made a variant for a 2 winged light cruiser (makes them much easier to identify on the table)

1/06/2018 Added a transport ship to the roster.

1/12/2018 Added an updated version of the battleship with separate fins.

Thanks to madkite for this great snowflake model. I loved his design of the snowflake and thought it would look great if I could add it on my fridge. I took the model and edited it so someone could put a 8mm x 3mm magnet on it. It really does look great.

Add some superglue in the hole, add the magnet, wipe off excess superglue, let dry and viola. Instant fridge magnet :)

I am a serious novice and it has taken me ages to put this together.
I wanted to make this with a bit less wires and batteries to fit inside , it runs on Bluetooth Arduino, on a Android mobile . I have included two versions as i opted for AA batteries , but if you have a li-ion flat battery you can use the smaller base, i have built micro usb charge port on side. I stripped a micro usb from a phone charger and it fits a treat. But as i said i never opted to use it as used AA's.
Original parts for the rest of the robot arm can be found at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1015238
The code and App i used can be found at https://zhutarduino.wordpress.com/arduino-projects/arduino-bluetooth-servo-control-with-my-new-android-app/ Great tutorial.
Enjoy.

description.text:
This is a reed case for 12 English Horn reeds. You print two copies of the provide part. They connect with hinges I found in my local American hardware store. The closure is by way of two magnets pressed into holes formed in the parts. The reeds are held in place by using neoprene ribbon.

All in all a very simple case at a fraction of the cost of a wood case. Great for the musician with more reeds than spots left in that mahogany case.

For customization you can emboss a name on the top surface to jazz it up a bit.

Working on re-scaling this for oboe reeds.

http://www.millermarketingco.com/productpages/reed_case/reed_case.htm

Needed a coupler to attatch a hose to my mini grease gun to attatch to a awkward zerf fitting. Printed with PETG. It got the lube job done, but it is starting to ooze grease.

The remix applies a clock designed by holybaf (https://www.instructables.com/id/Arduino-Wireless-Power-POV-Display/) with snug's POV clock case. The Arduino Mini and LED's are powered wireless by a coil underneath. This effectively creates a transformer with the coil fixed to the rotating CD. It generates around 8V from a 5V source.

I created a board to mount the oscillator rather than use strip board. It also allowed me to use a medium power transistor to allow for a higher voltage (it can get really hot at 12V but is fine at 5V).

None of the RTC boards I had were really small. I designed a simple board that takes a DS1302 and 32.768kHz crystal and uses a header that aligns neatly with the Arduino. The battery used by the RTC to keep the time even when power isn't present is mounted as the counter weight for the Arduino and RTC boards.

The code that holybaf used seems to be used by many of these type of POV systems. It assumes the motor will spin at a constant speed and all timing is hardcoded. I have rewritten the code to use Timer1 to measure the rotation speed and Timer2 to output the leds based on the rotation speed.

description.text:
I really liked the PI3 case but wanted a more secure mount for the PI, the top bezel for the 5" display and an easy way to gain access to the SD card in the PI.

I added some vent holes to the bottom of the case, measured my fingers to see how big an access hole I'd need to re and re the Micro SD card.

A couple of tests later and version 2 has been working out pretty good.

There are two top bezels. One is labeled "relaxed" because on a couple of my 5" displays the TFT is actually over lapping the edge of the PCB board and there's no moving it. So I enlarged the area to give the display some "wiggle" room.

I use an M2.5 and M1.5 drill bit to pre-size the holes so the hex head bolts will start in easier.

The optimal location for my HTC Vive Lighthouses are in the corner of my living room. So I created this wall mount to help secure the lighthouse in a corner. My goal was to create something that did not require anything other than the standard mount and the two screws that come with it.

I also tried to reduce the amount of filament needed just to save printing time. The first prototypes had thinner walls, but would crack under applied force. I found 5mm wall to be satisfactory.

Make sure to apply force several times the weight of the lighthouse to the print until you are satisfied that print will not fail while holding the lighthouse.

In short, a fully printable, fully working padlock with a detachable shackle. And no, this is not a joke lock, this has an actual working five-lever tumbler mechanism and only opens with the correct key (or by lockpicking). See how it works: http://youtu.be/yzBI0HB2o-I

Use fine settings to print the body, bolt, key and tumblers. I used 0.20 layers and 0.36 track width. Update 30.7.2012: There's a file lever_padlock_tumblers.zip which contains the tumblers as individual STLs. It may be more convenient to get and print the tumblers as individual objects (using Slic3r's plater, for example) instead of re-exporting them as a batch every time when changing the bitting. The included key works with tumblers 3, 7, 4, 0, 2 counted from the bottom up. Sand the top surfaces of the tumblers and the bolt, these must slide against each other freely. Sand the bolt hole in the body, the bolt pin, the main shaft, the key guide shaft and the round holes in the tumblers and in the end of the key, if needed. (Update: I have only needed to sand the bolt and tumbler top surfaces and the key bitting, even for a 10-tumbler lock.) Assemble the bolt into the body first and check that the key operates it correctly without tumblers. The end of the key that operates the bolt may need a little sanding (it should be rounded). Assemble the tumblers into the body (the one at lowest Y position goes in first), checking that they move freely. Then finish the key. As printed, the tumblers probably won't fit between the high bitting positions, so widen the low positions by sanding until the tumblers slide into those freely. Try to operate the lock with the key - it should now work, but if it doesn't, check what's wrong and finetune things with sandpaper if necessary. Print, with coarser settings, the shackle and one of the chassis pieces (one is secure and one comes with a window to see the mechanism in action). The mechanism body can then be inserted into the chassis and the lock should be fully operational. If you want to change the bitting, just modify the bitting value array in the scad file and export the new tumblers and key. Everything is parametric. Some things (like chassis wall thicknesses and tumbler count) can be changed easily but the mechanism details have a lot of interdependencies, which need hand-tuning if something is changed. The mechanism itself is already smallest I could make reliably work with reasonable effort.

title: Toothpaste Tube Squeezer (with pin connector cap)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix of the Toothpaste Tube Squeezer by @somethingtohide which is itself a remix of this one by @ottenjr. Thanks for the design folks!

I really like the original design by @ottenjr, but it posed two problems for me:

  1. The overhangs wouldn't print properly on the flower shaped hole
  2. The cap didn't really fit securely enough and would come off every once in a while when rolling the toothpaste tube

The first problem was solved by @somethingtohide by switching to a hexagonal nut. Using superglue to solve the second problem seemed like an incomplete design to me.

So I went ahead and created a remix to use a pin connector for the cap. No glue necessary! Hope you like my tweak to the popular toothpaste squeezer!

Printer:

MP Select Mini v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Layer height: 0.2, Shell thickness: 1.2

Infill:

60

Notes:

If using PLA which is very hard and brittle, you might want to print the cap with a slightly lesser infill to allow some flex on the pin connector. I printed the cap with 0.2 mm layer height, 0.8 mm shell and 15% infill.

author: AnthonyKwon

title: Clip for Barrina LED T5 fixture

description.text:
The metal clips that come with the Barrina 4FT LED T5 Integrated Single Fixture off Amazon are very flimsy and come with a screw that is less than 1/2". This is not long enough to go through drywall for a long lasting connection on the garage ceiling. If you use a larger screw the head gets in the way and the clip won't catch the fixture.

I designed a new clip for drywall or deck screws and made the clip large enough to hold the ends of two fixtures when they are connected together with the included electrical connector. This clip can be used at end of a strip or between two fixtures. It does add about 4mm between the ceiling and fixture which is required for the screw head I used. You could reduce this with different screws (OpenScad script included).

The light fixtures are very light. When you install, you can start with a single clip on an end and then just add another clip at the other end between the next fixture. There is no need to measure between fixtures if you have a straight line to install on. A single screw (into wood) per clip will hold the fixture to the ceiling.

This is a simple print with nothing tricky. I printed at 50% infill in ABS. I did my test print in blue. Final prints are white to match ceiling and the fixture.

description.text:
I scaled it down to about 50%, added a loop to use as a hanger, and printed it with 0% Infill and 1.7mm shell thickness (4 shells) and 0.01mm bottom thickness (1 layer). I cut the bottom out and glued it to a 2xAA battery holder (http://www.digikey.com/short/tz5bd1) which had a switch (https://www.digikey.com/short/qcwd5b) and 10mm white LED (https://amzn.com/B00KNTP936) hot glued to it. It pulls about 7 mA, so should last the entire holiday season (I hope).

If I was going to do it again, I think I'd go with AAAs since it is a bit heavy for an ornament, and I don't think the battery life is an issue.

See a timelapse of the build at https://youtu.be/c-8Mll6QcIw

print_settings.Notes:: I recommend printing this with PETG or another semi-flexible filament, since it needs to be flexible enough to bend during installation, but stiff enough not to flop around while it is installed. Additionally, it needs to put up with some fairly high heat, which may be a problem if you print it in PLA. I printed with black Inland PETG (I didn't have any white), and it worked beautifully. The other three flaps are warped and gross, so I'll be replacing them as well.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2
print_settings.Infill:: Any. I used 100% because I wanted it to have the most thermal mass possible to avoid warping.

description.text:
We recently had a dryer vent flap break after about 20 years at my house. Rather than spending $18 on a whole new vent cover, I decided just to make a new flap.

Because isn't that the dream of 3D printing? Never having to buy something you can just make yourself?

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Anything. I used 0.2mm

Infill:

Any. I used 100% because I wanted it to have the most thermal mass possible to avoid warping.

Notes:

I recommend printing this with PETG or another semi-flexible filament, since it needs to be flexible enough to bend during installation, but stiff enough not to flop around while it is installed. Additionally, it needs to put up with some fairly high heat, which may be a problem if you print it in PLA. I printed with black Inland PETG (I didn't have any white), and it worked beautifully. The other three flaps are warped and gross, so I'll be replacing them as well.

This is a fan mount for the ft-5 using a stock extruder and fitting on the stock mount with a little modification. Recommended to print in two pieces and adhere together. Can be printed entirely at once. Uses on 40 mm fan, same as on the extruder.

To install:

Remove screws holding extruder motor to carriage
Drill from motor side halfway through carriage mount so screws holding fan mount are flush
Install mount using M3 10mm screws and flat square bolt as found in kit
Reinstall extruder motor
Adjust as needed

comments.author: nlnpereira

comments.text: V6 of the regular shroud is the latest. It's similar in shape to the current MK3 shroud and cools the best out of the designs I've uploaded. V2 of the C Shroud is the latest in that style which was supposed to bring more air to the back of the print beyond the pinda probe. Sadly it just isn't designed well enough to move enough air back behind the print so in essence it's total cooling potential isn't as good. I posted these without a ton of testing and in my situation my room temp is cooler than most as I print at my studio at around 19-20C. I have a little advantage that way so I uploaded all the designs so people could test and give feedback. I've done dozens of overhang tests and the V6 shroud is the BEST out of the bunch and better than the included shroud. The downfall being I designed it to MY printer and my nozzle is a little lower than some so it's a very tight fit and I need to redesign it a little higher.

author: delukart

description.text:
This is a project to convert the Ekocycle (Cube 3) printer that was gifted by Coca-Cola to robotics teams, into a functional printer using open filament, and open source software.

The parts for this were printed out of ABS on a Monoprice Select Mini V1, using a polycarbonate build plate. Ramps was chosen due to its flexibility as a platform, and its low price. The Ramps 1.4 board was converted to 24v due to the operating voltage of the motors (It runs terribly at 12v), and will hopefully be replaced with a custom Ramps design if I have the time.

The parts as uploaded are in some strange orientations, something that will need to be fixed. Everything should all be able to be printed without supports, though I would definitely recommend them.

A BOM will be uploaded when possible, as long as future updates to the printed parts.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Resolution:

0.175

Infill:

100%

title: Tevo Little Monster Duet3d adapter plate

description.text:
This is a Duet3d (wifi or Ethernet) adapter plate for the Tevo Little Monster that will let you use the existing holes on the TLM to mount your Duet3d controller. There are others on Thingiverse but I designed my own reinforced version to print in ABS.

My version of an adapter plate uses 3mm screw holes on a 2mm thick base-plate. The raised columns are 6.6mm in diameter and also take 3mm screws. I also shifted the raised mounts to be closer to one side of the base-plate so the front panel of the Duet3d control board won't sit so far back from the front edge of the TLM.

Tevo Little Monster

I printed this in ABS on the TLM's glass bed using Wolf-Bite ABS formula.
105C bed temp and 230 extruder temp.

description.text:
The original was a sphere of 100 mm. I have already scale it, now it's a 30 mm space station (not a moon). And the bore for the extruder is aprox. 5.5 mm diameter, fits quite good.

Printed the 3 parts at the same time, took about an hour.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini V2

Infill:

25 %

Notes:

No need for supports, just place everything on their flat side.

Make sure the bottom part fixes right into the extruder shaft. Try to force it to fit, or make the hole a little moldable by heating it.

Once the bottom part fits, glue the trench and then the top.

Good Luck, and may the force be with you!

description.text:
I was having issues with my PETSMART 17-3/4"(Bulb) fluorescent light hoods in which the bulbs would burn out quickly and being there was only 1 light per hood, there wasn't enough light to sufficiently cover the plants within the aquarium. After one of the ballasts burned I gave up on the fluorescent setup and decided it was best to invest in the LED lights and parts so that I am not constantly replacing bulbs and drivers in the future. now the tank looks bright and the plants look like they are finally growing healthily.

Remove the internal components and remove the plastic parts on the sides, fins and screw collar. Leave all of the screw collars on the bottom/top of the hoods. Keep the screws and reuse them with these new pieces. Print 1 set of left and right. Use the existing 2 fluorescent sockets from each hood along with the 2 new parts purchased. The light sockets press fit into the printed parts and are held down by the reused screws. Wire up the sockets using the existing wire as depicted in the wiring diagram provided with the bulbs. MAKE SURE YOU DO THIS RIGHT! Otherwise you will end up buying a new bulb or two.

I provided my GCODE along with this as reference. Tell me if you like it.

From Ebay, two of these: G13 T8 Fluorescent & LED Tube Lamp UL Holder Socket Fittings AC100-660V

From Ebay, two of these: 110/120V-LED F15T8 Tube Light (Rotatable)-Daylight-18"(17-3/4" Includes Pins)-7W

Printer:

Scalar

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

No

Notes:

author: RAMilewski

description.text:
These are brackets that I have made to mount Nema 17 stepper motors to a small milling table.

The “big part” is the main part. I have uploaded one with support material. The cylinder in the middle must be removed after the print. See picture.
I also uploaded a “big part” without support material for people who want to generate their own.

The small peace is to connect the shaft of the motor to the turning wheel of the table.

I printed this part in PET-G. This material is good in flexing a bit, which is an advantage if the motor shaft is not precise aligned. :-)

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing is a plug and play extruder work.It provides convenience in changing the hot end or the extrusion method (bowden or driect drive) without screw.

Hot end : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2720701
Cooling Fan :https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2721348

Requirements:

  • 22 pieces of 5x5x2 square or 5x2 disk neodymium n50 magnet
  • m3 screw in various sizes
  • Spring and ballbearing for lever
  • Extruder driver gear
  • OD:4mm ID:2mm PFTE tube
  • 4mm M6 female pineumatic connector
  • 4mm M6 tube (You can do it yourself with M6 threader from aluminum tube (OD:6mm ID:4mm))

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

%30

comments.text:
Nice try but although I thought about it in the past, I realized the added weight and complexity wasn't worth it. I preferred to simplify my mounts, one butterfly nut to remove the whole extruder/hotend, one screw to untighten to remove the hot end. Didn't even bother to make a lever actuated clamp. Indeed most of the time it takes to change is to disconnect the cables. Fact one can design a single connector/cable assy that would be part of the mount as done in some pro printer and a quick release system (done it for gun optics).
An other drawback of magnets is strength and should the hot end hit something it can fall.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Thank you for your comment. For me this is much more than an experiment. I have been using it for a long time and never encountered a problem. It will not be easy to fall the hot end except for the very low temperature or the height of the first layer that is not well adjusted. In addition, a strong adhesive must be used to glue the magnets. The weight of the magnets used will be no more than the materials in the other methods. I think it's simple and useful.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
With PETG, often happens that blobs form on the bed, home position, print area ...and there you go, a collision.
Note I use magnets not just for holding parts but as bearings, springs .... too.

description.text:
This nice printerbed calibration is designed with FREECAD. I have designed this for my Craftbot Plus printer but it can be used for every 3D-printer ofcourse. You can use and adapt this design for your own needs. I have added the Freecad-file also.

The original size of my design was for a 250x200 printerbed, but because I use a glass bed I have made it smaller: 190x140. Overall thickness is 2mm. The thicker calibration tabs are all 5mm.

How to use it:
Just print it and measure the heights in all corners to see if they have the same height. Also look at the flat surfaces: they must be looking good and flat too.
Adapt your bed if needed and print it again if you like.

Printer:

Craftbot Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4mm

Infill:

20%
I have added the GCODE file too, please use them only when you have an Craftbot Plus 3D-printer: the gcode is optimized for it. But ofcourse you can make your own gcode by using the .STL file.
I have used Freecad for the design, you can get it here: https://www.freecadweb.org/wiki/Download
PLEASE: don't forget to LIKE this design !!!

Yes, I don't have an use for this one... But I need to flex my Mechanical Engineering muscle! So I decided to remix rjewell999's modular plastic conveyor belt design. I based all my models on his, but wanted to modify the sprockets so I can fit my overseas-bought motor. Had a lot of fun designing and building this one! If you have an assembly line you could possibly use these to transport stuff around!

*The two bars on either side are to make sure the I beams don't move apart from each other (happened). They were designed a posteriori, and are a bodge. Feel free to change that!

I published the Inventor files if you want to modify them. Have fun!

Video of the working model uploaded here:
https://youtu.be/mo3IvrBnOnA
https://youtu.be/7cM0Jle0LSw

estudiantes de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia.

García P. estudiante de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia y dirigido por el Ingeniero Mecatrónico Cristian Silva estudiante de Doctorado en la Universidad Nacional de Colombia. Todos estos archivos están cubiertos por la licencia creativa atribución bienes comunes. No comercial, por favor utilice la referencia de nosotros si desea imprimirlo.

Para niños de 3 a 16, el consentimiento fue explicado por el investigador principal y firmada por los niños y sus padres. el consentimiento informado por escrito de los padres se obtuvo con el fin de publicar las imágenes y vídeos que aparecen en el estudio de investigación y la investigación. Assemble using 3mm bolts and nuts.
Designed using Fusion 360.

I found both my Solidoodle & Myriwell Direct Drive extuders didn't have quite enough Stepper grunt, if I tightened the Tension Spring too much the Stepper Motors skipped steps.

I wasn't happy with any existing Geared Extruers - so here is my version.

It can be used as a standard Bowden Extruder, or do what I did with my Solidoodle andmake an adapter to screw the Geared Extruder to my E3D-V6 hotend.

I found the best way to mount the Bowden Pneumatic connectors was to run a 6mm tap thru , the BSP adapter, then glue it into the body

It's been working for several months now, no problems found (so far)

description.text: The laminator in our lab only operated if the cover was in place but as we were using it to create microfluidic chips we needed better access to the rollers.  I designed this little widget to hold the two contact switches closed so the laminator thinks that the cover is in place.
Print out then fix to the laminator; mine has magnets so I added a small screw to hold the widgets in place.

title: Adventurer's Camp - Portable Anvil and Tools - 28mm gaming

description.text:
Saw a cool resin sculpt online today that inspired me to make a "portable anvil" piece for my Adventurer's Camp! A portable anvil is the type that can be thrown into a wagon and moved from camp to camp. This release has 3 different versions:

  • Basic version of an anvil attached to a stump
  • Basic version + tools (multiple hammers, a pliers, a hand bellows, and a horseshoe on the anvil)
  • Basic version w/ tools + a length of chain wrapped around and dangling from the anvil.

The versions with more items look cooler but are increasingly more complex and tedious to paint. I am VERY happy with how this model turned out from both a detail and final product standpoint. The version in the picture was printed @ .08mm layer height with no supports and took about an hour to print.

See the complete "Adventurer's Camp" collection

If you like my free items on Thingiverse, check out my stuff for sale on Hero's Hoard, and follow EC3D on Facebook where I give away premium model sets to a follower twice a month!

title: Furry Hexmas Tree (single and dual extrusion)

description.text:
Merry Christmas!

Print without supports, minimal infill (I used 5%) Both versions included, single and dual extrusion.

I printed 2 trees, one at 0.2mm and the green one at 0.3, the purple one probably printed a bit better at 0.2 but both came out fine. I ran 2 shells on the green, 3 shells on the purple, 3 shells had less casualties on the branches when removing the cone.

There was a few ways I thought about doing a hairy tree, many of the attempts at branches and fancy things just yielded a painful print, where as this is about as easy a print as you can get and you can print it super fast also. Stands at just under 15cm tall, higher with the star. The Star is a bit big, but ah well.

Removal of outer cone is super easy, I just used a kitchen knife and cut around the inside, place in a bowl of hot hot water for a minute and then mold to shape, hair dryer works too but a little aggressive sometimes.

description.text:
UPDATE 01.01.2018

I Changed the design of the button faceplate as I encountered problems with buttons pressed unwanted in my pockets. I added some "same hight" bars so the buttons isnt so easy pressed when you have the key fob in your pocket.

4 months ago I crashed my car, it was all my fault, completely overworked and tired ( no alcohol or drugs involved!) So for 4 months I was carless, depending on others, including a lot and lof of waiting for rides, couldnt go anywhere. Had to save hardcore to finally be able to buy a new ( old used) car. So finally last friday I bought one, but as it wasnt registered I only got the papers and keys to be able to register it. They key it came with was done, I mean literaly DONE, it was more of a pile of glued, ugly sticky plastic, one of those flipping knife like keyfobs very common at volkwagen cars. I put it appart and used the main key blade in a standard vw keyholder+ imobilizer chip. the remote electronic did not fit in a common key blade holder so I created my own little remote case for it. The car is almost 17 years old and only featured open and close on the remote, so no fancy trunk or panic button ;)
It only supports the remote electronic boad visible on the disassembly picture. Instead of the super tiny CR1620 it uses two big CR2032 which should last like 4 times as long as the small ones would ;) The Back plate can be customized if wanted, I of course used my LWC logo on it :D

For this build you need quite a big washer or the original springloaded battery holder.
A short wire needs to be soldered on the green marked area on the ciruit board to the minus side of the washer/ or springloaded battery contact.

2x CR2025 Battery
hotluge gun

Nice design try BUT HORRIBLY WRONG HORN design!

telavox.web.fc2.com/speaker.html

Youre whole horn-construction is not in use, the horn-mouth is too small, there is no compression chamber behind the speaker.
I have built horn-speaker enclosures for over 50 years, from small ones with 1 4" driver up to very big ones with 2 15" drivers, so I think I may put a few cents info in.
Please leave a message if you think I am wrong....

These wheels are self-designed ones for 3D printing. I needed some for my Dynam FW 190 to complete my retract mod.

The construction is based on original photos, not quite to scale, but close to it.
To simplify the project the two halfes of the model rim are identical - the original one differs in function and look.

Printing of the tire was realized with a flexible Filament called "Innoflex", with 5% filling - then smoothed with abrasive paper and refined additionally with a thin layer liquid rubber.
Rim is printed conventional with Pro-HT-Filament (2x per wheel). It is modified to impact strength. This can not be bad for a wheel.

Size is exactly 80 x 20mm, a little bit smaller than given scale.

description.text:
This is a tool to help open PET-bottles. It was developed for a school project at KTH Royal Institute of Technology in Stockholm, Sweden.

The name comes from the resemblance of the Egyptian hieroglyph, Udjat(Horus eye).

Print in two pieces for best results.

Printer:

Perfect 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

If you have flexible filament, print the model in two pieces. If you print in one filament hard plastic the bottle cap will probably slip.

Print either:

  • Body_opener.stl - In hard plastic
  • Insert_opener.stl - In flexible plastic
    Assemble

or

  • Openeronepiece.stl - In hard plastic

Background

Many people may ask 'Why would anyone need help to open pet bottles?'.

It turns out that grip strength doesn't peak before your mid thirties. This means that the average female 20 year old has similar grip strength to that of a 80 year old male or a 55 year old female.

Link to the study

Graph from "Grip Strength across the Life Course: Normative Data from Twelve British Studies" showing grip strength depending of age and sex.
I just wanted to add to the ornament fever on here.

title: anet a8 mainboard and mosfet mount

description.text:
This is a mount for anet a8 board and 2 mosfets (bed and heater block). These mosfets are described by amazon like Hrph 3D Printer Heated Bed Performance Kit High Power 210 A MOSFET.
Their size is different from regular 3d mosfets so i had to make a mount base for myself. The mosfet mount has been made with offset for clearing the space taken for stepper motor mount.

Mount base is bolted on top 4 anet a8 board holes. The other holes are floated. I didn't had to use nuts. The bolts are tightened snuggly to the mount. No additional holes needed in frame.

Please forgive me for some cosmetic defects but i was not fluent with 3d sketching programs by that time.

comments.text: you shouldn't have to sand the pegs, however I did take a sharp knife and clean up the supports, and ran it into the slit in the peg.  The point of the slit is so that it will compress and allow the gears to slide on then pop back out.  Make sure nothing is in the slit. description.text:
Quickly measure the right amount of tea leaves for one pot, or other granular materials where you need the same amount every day:

  • Place the funnel on the portioner, over the closed measuring cup.
  • Pour in the tea leaves until the cup is a bit over full.
  • Hold the chute hole over your tea tin.
  • Carefully slide off the funnel, striking the measuring cup and pouring the extra tea back into the tin.
  • The measure now contains the right amount of tea. Pour it into the filter or teapot. I use my funnel and stand for this.

It works reasonably well one handed.

This is the second design for this purpose. I renamed the first one to old tea portioner.

The stand is not strictly required, but useful to keep the bottom of the portioner clean, and, depending on the sizes, to stabilize it a bit.

There are STL files for a number of sizes. 47 cm³ and 66 cm³ are the right amount of rooibos tea for my two teapots, 1 dm³ and 1.4 dm³. For other sizes you should use the customizer, or (when it is not working) download the scad file, load it into OpenSCAD on your computer,set the volume and generate the three parts there. When you have a mass, look up the density in the FAO list, elsewhere, or measure yourself. Americans should look up the millilitres per teaspoon &c. in this list, and visit metric4us at their leisure after they printed their portioner.
As a reminder to everybody, millilitre and ml are just synonyms for cubic centimetre and cm³, as are litre, l, L or ℓ for cubic decimetre and dm³.

While i prefer this style, where you pour the tea, especially when you’re almost out of tea, there is, of course nothing wrong with using measuring spoons or scoops like things 682146 or 619626. Except from the use of lots of useless units, like two “fl.oz.”. That there are different fluid ounces is one of the many, big problems with non-SI units. Anyway, for both you should just use 30 cm³ instead. (When you need precision, you should use a graduated cylinder.)

Printer:

GeeeTech i3 pro C

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 µm

Infill:

10 %

Notes:

Print this with low infill and enough top layers and perimeters. This should be an easy print. No falsework or similar required. The stand can be printed with 300 µm layers without problems.

After using my now old tea portioner a while, i noticed that the chute didn’t do its job all that well. I often spilled some tea leaves. So, instead of tweaking it here and there, i came up with this new design. It is, all in all, somewhat heavy. If you want to save a bit of filament, you can stick to the old one. I also used a simpler shape for the measuring space itself, simplifying the calculation considerably.

There are some more values that can be changed, like the height of the cylindrical section of the measuring space. Load the SCAD file into OpenSCAD on your computer and tweak them there.

There is some design history available at my github repo.

• PLA seems to be better suited for food use than ABS, so you should use that. Or maybe PETG
  • You should probably clean your nozzle once, to get rid of mineral oil and other residues.
  • When you use an oiler, use a suitable oil. Maybe a vegetable oil or something like Ballistol oil.
  • The food comes into contact with the printed parts for only a short time, and it is usually dry, so it should hardly be effected at all.
  • When you use this for tea leaves, germs shouldn’t be too much of a problem either, as you pour boiling water over the leaves, which should deal with that. You should still keep the thing clean, of course.

These two articles shed some more light on the issue:

  • 10 things you need to know about 3D printing & food safety
  • Food Safe Video

In the end, it is up to you. I can take no responsibility.

comments.text:
There seems to have been some confusion on how to customize this with OpenSCAD on your own PC.
I didn’t want to write too much in the main description. So.
You have to first change the sizes &c. and then do the render (F6) and export three times, for the three parts separately. Write "part = "portioner";”, “part = "funnel"”, “part = "stand"” at the top and do render & export for each.
But then again, the customizer is working at the moment.

Want wireless phone charging in your Tesla Model S?

This is simply a phoneholder that you glue onto a Qi chargeplate.
The unit is friction-fitted into the console of Tesla Model S. (might be a little snug, so be careful)

  • This was created to fit with the "Samsung Fast Charge" charger, but you could easily scale the model for any Qi chargeplate, or edit the sketchup-model for your needs.

NOTE: I found out that the Tesla still powers its USB ports even after you turn off the car, so I'd invest in a usb-cable with an on/off switch, in case the Qi plate drains power when not in use.
Also, note that this was created for the facelfit version of Model S. - not sure if the center-console is different on older models.

print_settings.Notes:: Seal ring is printed with NinjaFlex

description.text:
I always wanted to have a bluetooth speaker. I thought, why not design and build one. So here it is.

This bluetooth speaker contains two rechargeable 18650 battery's, so you have lots of listening fun without plugging it in your walloutlet. The front, back and body need support. I printed these parts with PLA and 0.2mm with 15% infill. The seal rings (you need two of them) have i printed with ninjafex.

I have heated up the brass knurls with a soldering iron. They slide right in the sockets. Be sure they are straight.

Update 19-12-2017: I've noticed, when playing on high volume (above in the red region of your phone volume) the connection will be lost or the device will shut down. (failsave) I think this has to do with the step up module. The step up module can't keep up stepping up the power for the amplifier board. I'm convinced the device can be much louder! Does anyone have a idea?

Parts you need for the build:

Brass inserts 24 pieces
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/100Pcs-M3x5mm-L-5mm-OD-Metric-Threaded-Brass-Knurl-Round-Insert-Nuts-LXM/32693221350.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.CsvCxE

LED base holder 3 pieces
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Hot-Sale-10pcs-3MM-Round-Chrome-Metal-LED-Light-Lamp-Emitting-Diode-Bezel-Lamp-Base-Holder/32808747894.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.CsvCxE

1Pair Black 78x41mm Bass Speaker Passive Radiator Auxiliary Bass Rubber Vibration Plate
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/1Pair-Black-78x41mm-Bass-Speaker-Passive-Radiator-Auxiliary-Bass-Rubber-Vibration-Plate/32785907739.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.M8oXrZ

m3x10 24 pieces
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/160PC-Metric-Thread-M3-Stainless-Steel-Hex-Bolt-Kit-304-Cap-Nut-Washer-Set-Screw/32794842281.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.EMQ1jk

description.text:
Under layout/table mount for servo control of turnout/swtiches. The mount is set up for the SG90 micro servos that are available on ebay. Holes are provided in the bracket for the screws that come to mount the servo. Very easy to install.

My layout is 1/2" plywood, plus 2 layers of 1/2" insulating foam, plus cork roadbed. I drill a 3/8" hole down through the layout. I then center the bracket on the hole underneath the layout and screw it to attach it. I then use .032 wire to connect the linking arm up through the newly drilled hole up into the hole between the rails. I will post more pictures soon.
https://youtu.be/8aHT2O79rHM
Enjoy!

description.text:
Bonjour,

C'est un kit de pièce pour monter votre support de tube dentifrice. Il permet de déposer à la verticale votre tube de dentifrice préféré, de prendre moins de place sur le comptoir et de la presser à mesure que vous le consommez pour en récupérer un maximum.

Il ne requiert aucune autre pièce (boulon, écrou, etc. du magasin) il est complet en soit avec ses cinq (5) pièces à imprimer.

Vous aurez besoin de fileter la pièce « Boulon d'axe de support » et « Axe pivot du support 01 » avec l'outillage pour des filets de M4 x 0.7.

Comme c'est une sorte d'outil, les pièces doivent avoir une force mécanique structurelle, c'est pour cela que je vous recommande de paramétrer l'impression avec un minimum de quatre (4) couches tout au tour (les côtés, le dessus, le dessous) et un remplissage de 20 à 25 %.

Si vous appréciez mes dessins techniques et en profitez, alors si vous avez les moyens de faire un don, je n'exige rien, mais je ne refuserai rien ! Voici ou me faire un don avec PayPal :

http://PayPal.Me/DonRR

Un grand merci !

L'ami René

description.text: Created out of necessity after finding multiple forgotten about gift cards, this slider box holds approximately 8 gift cards. I would think that increasing z access for a few more cards may work. I may add the blend file in the future. Initial print was PLA black and then I realized after printing the letters were in reverse.. duh. Next print I used PET Maroon but printed at the same PLA temp. I tried a higher temp print with PET and seemed to get more curl so went back to PLA temp settings. Images are printed at default PLA with low resolution. I may need to add some width to the side rails but seems to work and slide well. Since it is thinner, it would not make a good pocket carrier since the slider lid will probably come off. I designed it for putting on my sun visor, so I will probably update soon with a visor clip.

print_settings.Notes:: Cura for slice.

description.text:
After getting my Trinket M0, I tear down the reset button 3 times in 2 days. So I decided to make a case to protect it from my clumsy hands.

As I didn't find a case that fits my ideas, I designed my own. This case is intended to a development Trinket M0 (used on a breadboard), but, if appropriate, can be used for a final product. I tried to resemble the shape of the board to maintain the spirit.

You have to use a transparent filament, otherwise the light of the leds will not come out. Or maybe you don't want to let the light go out. You will need a tip to access the reset button.

As you can see, there is not any flange or screw holes to close it. So take the lid, snap it and apply heat, carefully, in the joints (just enough, otherwise will be harder to remove if needed) to melt the plastic into a single piece (with a soldering iron or pyrograph at about 200° (as 3D printers), clean afterwards properly!!!, or even better to use a tip just for this). So the board will be locked inside forever (OK, you can break the case or apply heat again, so forever it's a lot to say).

I called it V2 because I made a first attempt (but was disastrous, so better not to talk about it...).

title: Car Truck Load Bar Universal Factory Roof Rack Mount

description.text:
Need a "UNIVERSAL" LOAD BAR/ROOF RACK MOUNT that attaches to factory roof rails on SUVs, Cars, Trucks? This little brain child might help. Designed for Older Thule / Barecrafter "Square bars 1 1/4" x 7/8" or any others that fit those dimensions. pretty easy design. Bar fits in the 1 1/4" slot, a 3/8" x 4" bolt passes through above bar and clamps hold it all together. the V on the bottom is not perfect but fits a multitude of vehicles.

You basically need
4 - Printed feet
4 - 3/8" x 4" Bolts & Nuts (nylock is best so they don't vibrate off not that once clamped it will go any where)
8 - 2" wide u bolts or hose clamps to fit ( I like hose clamps as they don't scar the rails like u bolts as they snug down but u bolts are stronger)

Print and use at your own risk, some printers have layer adhesion issues which might cause failures, even though this design keeps everything in compression use common sense, don't overload, Bikes, Canoe, Kayaks, Skis, you get the idea.
